data.title: The 45 best architecture in New Delhi

placeMetadata.name: Red Fort

sources.snippet: Would you believe it if you were told that the Red Fort was once white?. It was originally made with lime plaster, but as it began to peel off, the British painted the fort red. Mughal emperor Aurangzeb made the Pearl Mosque near his chamber.
sources.shortName: A Tour Of New Delhis Architectural Landmarks

sources.snippet: If you're a history buff it's impossible that you'll be able to miss this one. While not as well-maintained as Agra Fort, the fortified palace that was built in the time of Shah Jahan brings alive the splendor and elegance of its Mughal court. Diwan - i - Aam and Diwan - i - Khas, Rang Mahal, Khas Mahal, Hamam, Delhi Gate, Lahori Gate, Moti Masjid, Naubat Khana, Hira Mahal, Shahi Burj are a few famous structures.

The Red Fort, one of the iconic historical places in Delhi, stands as a testament to India's rich cultural and architectural heritage. Commissioned by the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in the 17th century, this majestic fort showcases stunning red sandstone architecture. Today, it remains a symbol of India's historical grandeur and a must-visit destination for those exploring Delhi's rich past.
sources.shortName: 30 Historical Places In Delhi For A Heritage Tour 2024

sources.snippet: This enormous red sandstone fort is synonymous with Delhi and is a testimony of the glory of the Mughal Empire. Built in 1638 by Shah Jahan, it took around ten years to be completed. A UNESCO World Heritage Site, the Red Fort is octagonal in shape with walls adorned with flowers and calligraphy, typically in the style of beautiful Mughal era architecture.
sources.shortName: 17 Historical Monuments in Delhi | Monuments in Delhi

sources.snippet: Also known as Lal Qila, the Red Fort is said to represent the power and creativity of Mughal Empire, the dominant force on the Indian subcontinent for more than two centuries. The huge complex derives its name from the color of its walls, which are made from red sandstone.
sources.shortName: 12 famous buildings in India: From ancient wonders to modern marvels

placeMetadata.description: Landmark 17th-century Mughal fortress built in towering red sandstone, now a complex of museums.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Red Fort, located in Old Delhi, India, is a 17th-century Mughal fortress made of red sandstone. It was the main residence of the Mughal Emperors and was commissioned by Emperor Shah Jahan in 1638. The fort's design is credited to Ustad Ahmad Lahori, who also built the Taj Mahal.
placeMetadata.address: Netaji Subhash Marg, Lal Qila, Chandni Chowk, New Delhi, Delhi, 110006, India

reviews.reviewText:
The Red Fort is truly one of the most iconic landmarks of India and a must-visit in Delhi. üè∞
The architecture is stunning, with massive red sandstone walls, beautifully designed gates, and intricate carvings that showcase Mughal grandeur. Walking inside feels like stepping back into history.

The museum inside gives a good glimpse of India‚Äôs rich heritage, and the evening light & sound show is an amazing experience that brings the fort‚Äôs history to life.

‚úÖ Well-maintained in most parts
‚úÖ Good for photography üì∏
‚úÖ Great spot for history lovers and families

‚ö†Ô∏è Be prepared for crowds, especially on weekends. Carry water and wear comfortable shoes as the fort is huge and requires a lot of walking.

Overall, it‚Äôs a perfect mix of history, culture, and beauty ‚Äî a place every traveler should explore at least once!

As a foreign visitor, visiting the Red Fort early in the morning was an unforgettable experience. I arrived just before sunrise, and watching the first rays of light fall on the majestic red sandstone walls was simply breathtaking. The fort glowed in warm orange hues, and the peaceful atmosphere made it feel like time had slowed down.

The morning breeze, the quiet surroundings, and the birds chirping added to the beauty of the moment. Walking through the grand gates and exploring the historic structures inside felt like stepping back in time. I could sense the deep history and culture that this place holds.

After my visit, I felt calm, inspired, and deeply moved by the heritage of India. The Red Fort is more than just a monument ‚Äî it's a symbol of strength, beauty, and tradition. A must-visit, especially in the peaceful hours of the morning. Highly recommended!

A must-visit spot in Delhi! The Red Fort is beautifully built and very well maintained. Inside, you‚Äôll find spacious gardens, grand halls, and peaceful pathways to walk around and enjoy.

The place is clean, organized, and has good facilities for visitors. Security is well-managed, with guards around to ensure safety. Great for a relaxed outing or some quiet exploration. I had a great deep dive in history. Lot of audio visual means to experience.

When I Visit Red Fort in Delhi it‚Äôs fill me proud and amazed to watch our nation legacy that our Prime Minister addresses the nation on Independence Day.
The architecture was stunning and the place was well-maintained. It‚Äôs the place where you can watch India‚Äôs rich history, Mughal architecture, and cultural heritage. Lal Qila is the UNESCO World Heritage site. There you can walk through the structures like Diwan-i-Aam, Diwan-i-Khas, Rang Mahal, and Moti Masjid displays brilliance of Mughal architecture. The museum inside gives a deep insight into the Mughal era.
The evening light and sound show is also worth watching.
Please visit early morning or evening to avoid heat and enjoy peaceful vibes. Just at the entrance there is a market where you can buy souvenirs, perfumes, jewelry, bags, hats and many more things. Red Fort offers a blend of beauty, history, and culture that‚Äôs hard to miss. Must visit place.

The Red Fort is a grand reminder of India‚Äôs rich history and stunning Mughal architecture. Walking through its massive gates and red sandstone walls feels like stepping back in time. The fort is spread across a huge area, so be prepared for a fair amount of walking ‚Äî comfortable shoes are a must.

You can book tickets online, with options to include or skip the museum. I recommend including it if you're interested in learning more about India‚Äôs heritage. The museums are well-curated and add depth to the visit.

Inside the fort, you‚Äôll also find small shops selling souvenirs, snacks, and local crafts, which adds a lively touch to the experience. It can get a bit crowded, especially during weekends and holidays, but the vibe remains enjoyable.

Overall, it's a must-visit if you're in Delhi ‚Äî both for its historical significance and the experience of exploring one of India‚Äôs most iconic landmarks. üáÆüá≥

I have visited the Red Fort many times, and each visit feels equally special. The last time I went was on 15th August 2025 ‚Äì Independence Day, which made the experience even more memorable. Being at the fort on this day carries a unique sense of pride, as it is not only a historical monument but also the very place where India celebrates its freedom with the Prime Minister‚Äôs address and the flag hoisting ceremony.

The architecture of the fort never fails to impress me ‚Äì the majestic red sandstone walls, beautifully crafted gates, and intricately designed structures inside reflect the grandeur of the Mughal era. Walking through its corridors feels like stepping back in time and reliving the pages of history.

Apart from the monuments and historical significance, the fort also has some nice shops inside where visitors can buy souvenirs. These shops offer handicrafts, miniature replicas, and other items that make for good keepsakes to remember the trip.

Overall, the Red Fort is not just a monument but a living symbol of India‚Äôs history and heritage. Visiting it on Independence Day added an emotional and patriotic dimension to my experience, making it truly unforgettable.

We visited red fort on Saturday. We planned to watch the light and sound show in the evening but unfortunately the show was cancelled that day due to rains. Better to check if the show would take place or not before but in tickets. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend buying tickets on book my show for this show as there is no guarantee for the show to commence.

It's not just a fort, there are multiple beautiful buildings inside, so if you are planning to go here you'll have a lot of fun seeing those buildings. It was totally different from what I was expecting, which was just a red coloured fort, but this turned out to be much more exciting and beautiful than that.

placeMetadata.name: Jama Masjid

sources.snippet: Shah Jahan commissioned the construction of Jama Masjid after Red Fort, once he changed his capital from Agra to Shahjahanabad (Old Delhi). The construction in red sandstone and marble took about six years and its interiors resemble the Jama Masjid in Agra. The courtyard floor is made of sandstone with marble strips indicating prayer positions to the common citizen.
sources.shortName: A Tour Of New Delhis Architectural Landmarks

sources.snippet: The Masjid-i JahƒÅn-NumƒÅ, commonly known as the Jama Masjid of Delhi, is the largest mosque in India. It was built by Mughal emperor Shah Jahan between 1644 and 1658 at a cost of 1 million rupees, and was inaugurated by an imam from Bukhara, present-day Uzbekistan. The mosque was completed in 1656 AD with three great gates, four towers and two 40 m high minarets constructed of strips of red sandstone and white marble.
sources.shortName: Delhi Architecture | List of Famous Delhi Buildings and Landmarks

sources.snippet: The courtyard is capable of accommodating 25000 worshippers and numerous Pigeons, this old masjid takes you a step closer to the divine. The mosque was commissioned by Shah Jahan this mosque was the product of the labor of around 6000 workers over the course of six years. You should visit the site with shoes on, as the red sandstone floor of the mosque is extremely hot on your feet.

Jama Masjid, located in the heart of Old Delhi, is one of the prominent historical places in Delhi. Constructed by the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan, this grand mosque is an architectural marvel and one of the largest mosques in India. Its impressive design and historical significance make it a must-visit destination for those exploring the rich heritage of Delhi.
sources.shortName: 30 Historical Places In Delhi For A Heritage Tour 2024

placeMetadata.description: 17th-century, red sandstone Mughal-style mosque with a 25,000 capacity & 40m high minarets.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Jama Masjid, a magnificent 17th-century Mughal-style mosque located in India, is a stunning example of Mughal architecture. Built by Emperor Shah Jahan, it features red sandstone and marble structures with impressive minarets reaching 40 meters high. The mosque's vast courtyards can accommodate up to 25,000 worshippers and offer picturesque views for visitors.
placeMetadata.address: Old Delhi, Delhi, 110006, India

reviews.reviewText:
Visited on July 7th, 2025 ‚Äì Day 4 in India

After taking a break yesterday to explore the markets, we continued our sightseeing today with our private tour guide. Our morning began at Rajghat, and from there we made our way to Jama Masjid.

It‚Äôs one of the largest mosques in India and a true architectural marvel, built centuries ago during the Mughal era. As soon as we arrived, we were swept into the lively energy of Old Delhi‚Äîthe sounds, the colors, the movement‚Äîit‚Äôs a kind of chaos that somehow feels alive and exciting rather than overwhelming.

The climb up the steps to the mosque was a fun adventure for our daughters (5 and 7), who took it on like a challenge and loved every minute. Once we entered the vast open courtyard, everything shifted. The noise faded, and it felt incredibly peaceful and calm inside. There‚Äôs something very spiritual about standing there, surrounded by towering minarets, marble domes, and centuries of history.

Our girls were full of curiosity, asking questions about how people pray, what the call to prayer means, and why everyone was barefoot. It turned into a beautiful moment of quiet reflection and learning. We took our time to take it all in, and even in the middle of a bustling city, it felt like we were in our own quiet world.

We absolutely loved this visit‚Äîit was meaningful, memorable, and full of life. Highly recommend for anyone traveling through Delhi, especially with kids who are curious and adventurous üôèüèΩ.

These monuments are beautiful, amazingly and well built structures. The architecture is so impressive. Some of the structures are still intact. But the Place doesn't maintain properly it looks so dirty mainly in the exterior.

If you tour guide says this is biggest mosque of India, It is absolutely lies. Biggest mosque of India is in Bhopal (MP).
3 Onion Shapes domes with 2 Minars (Tower) this particular Persian design introduced by Shahjahan in 17th Century & copied by across the globe. Therefore, Jama Mosque is famous bcz of its unique architecture.
The mosque has a peaceful atmosphere despite being in the heart of busy Chandni Chowk. A must-visit for history, culture, and photography lovers!

It is a very beautiful also a very rushy mosque...
Children should be kept safely when visiting this place. It is very crowded.
The shops infront are provided different varieties of things.
The food Street which is situated at the back provides very delicious different varieties...
Time goes very speedily when we keep enjoying that big area....

I visited Jama Masjid yesterday, and while the architecture is absolutely stunning‚Äîa magnificent display of Mughal artistry with grand domes, intricate marble work, and an expansive courtyard that makes you feel the weight of history‚Äîthe experience was far from perfect. The premises and surrounding area were not well maintained, with dirty walkways, open drains emitting unpleasant smells, and a large, unmanaged crowd both inside and outside the mosque, which made moving around difficult and diminished the peacefulness such a place should offer. The nearby market, though vibrant and full of life, felt chaotic and poorly organized, adding to the sense of disorder, and I truly believe it would benefit from proper management, covered drains, and better sanitation. From what I have seen in other people‚Äôs accounts, my impressions are widely shared‚Äîmany visitors praise the sheer beauty and spiritual presence of Jama Masjid but express disappointment about the lack of cleanliness, the overwhelming number of visitors at any given time, and the constant haggling or touting near the entrances. While the breathtaking view from the minaret and the sense of stepping into a living piece of history remain unforgettable highlights, the lack of upkeep and effective crowd control significantly detract from what could otherwise be a truly majestic experience, and for that reason I would rate my visit 3 out of 5.

Jama Masjid is a stunning and peaceful mosque right in the heart of Old Delhi. The architecture is beautiful, and walking through the huge courtyard feels like stepping back in time. A must-do is climbing up the minaret (tower) ‚Äì from the top you get a breathtaking view over the city, with sights like the Red Fort clearly visible in the distance. Entry is inexpensive (400 Rupien, 200 extra for the tower), and it‚Äôs one of the absolute highlights of Delhi.

The Masjid campus inside is good. Washrooms very dirty. You can also go up one of a minar; you just have to buy a ticket  of Rs. 100. It‚Äôs very crowded outside the masjid, take care of your belongings. Opens at 11 AM.

VISITED JAMA MASJID IN DELHI, AND IT‚ÄôS TRULY A MASTERPIECE OF MUGHAL ARCHITECTURE! THE GRANDEUR OF THE MOSQUE, WITH ITS MASSIVE COURTYARD AND STUNNING RED SANDSTONE AND MARBLE WORK, IS BREATHTAKING. THE INTRICATE DETAILS AND THE SERENE ATMOSPHERE MAKE IT A MUST-VISIT. CLIMBING THE MINARET OFFERS AN INCREDIBLE VIEW OF OLD DELHI, THOUGH IT‚ÄôS A BIT OF A SQUEEZE! THE PLACE IS WELL-MAINTAINED, BUT IT CAN GET CROWDED, SO EARLY MORNINGS ARE BEST. RESPECTFUL ATTIRE IS A MUST, AND THE STAFF ARE HELPFUL IN GUIDING VISITORS. A PERFECT BLEND OF HISTORY, CULTURE, AND SPIRITUALITY.
THANK YOU . . . .

placeMetadata.name: Humayun‚Äôs Tomb

sources.snippet: Humayun‚Äôs Tomb is special because its architecture would eventually become the inspiration for the Taj Mahal‚Äôs design, one of the Seven Wonders of the World. Commissioned in 1569 after Mughal emperor Humayun‚Äôs death in 1556, the tomb‚Äôs main architect was Mirak Mirza Ghiyas from Persia. The 25-acre plot on which the tomb is built has a four-squared garden that is further divided into 36 identical squares.
sources.shortName: A Tour Of New Delhis Architectural Landmarks

sources.snippet: Humayun's Tomb, a UNESCO World Heritage Site in Delhi, stands as one of the most iconic historical places in the city. Built in the mid-16th century, this majestic tomb is a striking example of Mughal architecture, featuring intricate designs and a picturesque garden setting. It serves as a testament to the rich historical and cultural legacy of Delhi, drawing visitors from around the world.
sources.shortName: 30 Historical Places In Delhi For A Heritage Tour 2024

Its construction with red sandstone and white marble creates a captivating contrast on the facade, making it visually delightful for visitors and photographers.

reviews.reviewText:
This place is a timeless masterpiece‚Äîbeautifully designed, expertly crafted, and, most importantly, impeccably maintained.

Surrounded by the iconic Char Bagh-style garden, its grandeur is further elevated. Even the indoor spaces are thoughtfully built and meticulously preserved.

As you step into the main tomb structure, a noticeable drop in temperature and the gentle flow of cool air reveal the brilliance of the architects of that era.

The stunning contrast of white marble and red sandstone on the outer walls enhances its beauty, while the raised platform gives the monument an even more imposing presence.

The lush gardens around it provide the perfect spot to sit, unwind, and soak in the serene atmosphere.

An absolutely magnificent experience.

You can feel a calm vibe there, far from city noise. The architecture is so grand but also somehow simple. I really think everyone should visit once, to see how beautiful and emotional history can be.

I visited Humayun‚Äôs Tomb this weekend, and it was a truly beautiful experience. The monument is incredibly well-preserved and gives you a deep sense of Mughal history and architecture. The gardens are lush and symmetrical, perfect for a peaceful walk or some quiet time with nature.

The entry was smooth, and the place was clean and well-maintained. I‚Äôd recommend visiting early in the morning or late afternoon to avoid the heat and crowds. Don‚Äôt forget to carry water and wear comfortable shoes, as there‚Äôs a lot to explore.

placeMetadata.name: Safdarjung Tomb, Delhi

sources.snippet: Safdarjung Tomb is the mausoleum of Mirza Muqim Abul Mansur Khan‚Äîpopularly known as Safdar Jung‚Äîmade in sandstone and marble. After his death, his son Nawab Shujaud Daula pleaded with the Mughal emperor to permit him to erect a tomb for his father in Delhi. The tomb was designed by an Abyssinian architect and was made to resemble Humayun‚Äôs Tomb.
sources.shortName: A Tour Of New Delhis Architectural Landmarks

sources.snippet: Safdarjung Tomb, a prominent historical place in Delhi, stands as a testament to Mughal architectural grandeur. Built in the mid-18th century, this mausoleum honors Safdarjung, the Prime Minister of the Mughal Empire. Surrounded by lush gardens, the tomb is an exquisite example of Mughal-era craftsmanship and remains a must-visit site for those exploring historical places in Delhi.
sources.shortName: 30 Historical Places In Delhi For A Heritage Tour 2024

sources.snippet: The last member of Mughal architecture is visible in this huge tomb garden. This tomb, which is enclosed, was constructed to commemorate Safdarjung Minister in the city of Avadh during the period of Muhammad Shah. Although it has a lot in common with the Humayun's Tomb, it is less impressive in comparison to the Humayun's Tomb.

reviews.reviewText:
It was an absolutely delightful place. It emanated peace and calm amidst always busy Delhi. The best time to visit will be the time for sunset according to me. The vibe of the place is immaculate. With parrots, peacocks and pigeons roaming around on the grounds, it is like an oasis of peace in the chaos of the city.

The tomb is majestic although crumbling. The entry gate itself is an example of brilliant architecture. The intricate details and designs will leave you craving for more time with those walls.

The ticket is purchased online. And it remains open till 7 pm, after that they shut it down.

Truly underrated, very less crowed but supreme in beauty. Ticket costs approx 50. Surrounded by gardens, though not very well kept due to less crowd. If you are lucky you can spot a peacock or two. Delighted to have visited this place of beauty and such architecture.

The place is clean, beautifully maintained, and surrounded by peaceful gardens. The Mughal architecture is stunning, and the calm atmosphere makes it perfect for a relaxing visit away from the city‚Äôs hustle.

Safdarjung Tomb is a really peaceful and underrated spot in Delhi. It‚Äôs not crowded at all, which makes it perfect for a quiet stroll or just relaxing with friends. The architecture is beautiful and gives off serious aesthetic vibes great for those Insta worthy pictures! If you're looking to spend a calm evening away from the city chaos, this is definitely a nice place to check out

Safdarjung Tomb is one of those monuments in Delhi that often gets overshadowed by Humayun‚Äôs Tomb or Qutub Minar, but honestly, it deserves equal attention. Located right next to Safdarjung Airport, it‚Äôs very easy to reach by metro or road. The entry tickets are affordable (cashless payment options are available), and usually the place is not too crowded, which makes the visit very relaxed.

The tomb itself is an impressive piece of Mughal architecture, built in 1754. The central dome and red sandstone structure with marble detailing look stunning, especially during early mornings or late afternoons when the sunlight falls beautifully on the arches. The gardens are laid out in the Mughal charbagh style, with symmetrical pathways and water channels, which are perfect for a peaceful walk.
What I liked most is the calm atmosphere here.

Unlike some other crowded monuments in Delhi, Safdarjung Tomb is relatively less crowded, which makes the visit more enjoyable. You can walk leisurely, admire the architectural details, and even sit under the trees to soak in the serenity.  It gives you enough space to appreciate the history and architecture. It‚Äôs also a great spot for photography, as the wide lawns, long corridors, and majestic gateways give excellent frames.

Facilities are decent. There are benches around the gardens. The ticket counter staff are polite, and the ASI has maintained the monument well. There is ample free parking. Nearby you can also visit Lodhi Garden or Khan Market for food and coffee after your tour.

Overall, Safdarjung Tomb is a hidden gem in Delhi‚Äôs heritage trail. If you are looking for history, architecture, or just a peaceful place to unwind in the middle of the city, this is a perfect spot. Highly recommended for both tourists and locals.
Beautiful place to spend time. You can book online as well as offline tickets. The place is peaceful not at all crowded. So one can spend good time.

Safdarjung Tomb  great spot to hang out with friends . It‚Äôs not crowded at all. The entry gate itself is an example of brilliant architecture.

A beautifully maintained monument and The Mughal-era architecture looks stunning. Beautiful gardens and you can find many peacocks there roaming.
Perfect for a peaceful walk and photography. its great place .

A hidden gem in the middle of Delhi and a beautiful creation of Mughal era. It's very peaceful and not so crowded like other monuments. Beautiful gardens and you can find many peacocks there roaming. Most recommended place for relaxing and natural beauty of the gardens where the national bird 'Peacock' lives.

placeMetadata.name: Jantar Mantar

sources.snippet: Jantar Mantar, located in the heart of Delhi, stands as one of the prominent historical places in Delhi. Built by Maharaja Jai Singh II in the 18th century, this astronomical observatory showcases a collection of architectural instruments designed for celestial observations. Visitors can explore the site to witness the historical significance and intricate astronomical instruments that make Jantar Mantar an essential destination for those interested in Delhi's rich cultural heritage.
sources.shortName: 30 Historical Places In Delhi For A Heritage Tour 2024

sources.snippet: Jantar Mantar was constructed by Maharaja Jai Singh of Jaipur in 1724. It is essentially an observatory that was made with the purpose of accumulating astronomical occurrences and information to help predict the time and the movements of celestial bodies such as the sun, moon and other planets. The Jantar Mantar has various instruments such as the Samrat Yantra, Jayaprakash Yantra and the Misra Yantra that helped with predictions.
sources.shortName: 17 Historical Monuments in Delhi | Monuments in Delhi

sources.snippet: Â∞èÊÄùÊñáThe observatory is also a very old building, with a lot of red paint falling off, and this building is not large, similar to an inverted heart-shaped structure, surrounded by new modern-style buildings in the city, and the whole visit cannot be accessed inside.
sources.shortName: 10 Top Attractions in New Delhi (2024)

placeMetadata.description: 13 architectural astronomy instruments built in 1724 at the orders of Mughal emperor Muhammad Shah.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Jantar Mantar, a remarkable site built in 1724 under the direction of Mughal emperor Muhammad Shah, is an extraordinary collection of 13 architectural astronomical instruments. This UNESCO World Heritage Site, crafted by Maharaja Jai Singh II of Jaipur, showcases the ingenuity and scientific prowess of its time. Designed to track celestial movements‚Äîsuch as those of planets and stars‚Äîthese impressive structures feature intricate Zodiac illustrations and stunning curves that captivate visitors.
placeMetadata.address: Sansad Marg, Janpath, Connaught Place, New Delhi, Delhi 110001, India

reviews.reviewText:
Visited Jantar Mantar recently and it was a fascinating experience. The site is full of massive astronomical instruments built centuries ago, and it‚Äôs amazing to see how advanced the science of timekeeping and astronomy was at that period. The architecture is unique, and every structure has its own purpose, which makes it a great spot for history and science lovers.

Jantar Mantar is truly a fascinating place where history, science, and architecture come together. Visiting it feels like stepping back in time to when astronomical observations were made without modern technology, yet with incredible accuracy. The collection of instruments here‚Äîmassive sundials, celestial observation tools, and various geometric structures‚Äîare not only scientifically important but also visually stunning. Each monument has a purpose, from tracking star positions to predicting eclipses, and you can still imagine how scholars centuries ago used them.

What I appreciated most was the way the site reflects India‚Äôs scientific heritage. The structures are so precise and carefully designed that they continue to spark curiosity even today. If you‚Äôre someone who loves astronomy, history, or architecture, this place is a gem.

The grounds are well-maintained, though I‚Äôd recommend hiring a guide or using the audio guide, as it helps you understand the function of each instrument much better. Without it, the place can just look like a collection of unusual stone structures.

Jantar Mantarwas one of the most fascinating experiences of my trip. This remarkable site, built by Maharaja Jai Singh II in the 18th century, is not just a collection of giant instruments but a testimony to India‚Äôs advanced knowledge of astronomy and science centuries ago.
The structures here are both artistic and scientific. Each instrument, from the massive Samrat Yantra (the world‚Äôs largest sundial) to the Jai Prakash and Ram Yantra, was designed with such precision to measure time, predict eclipses, and track the movement of stars and planets. Standing next to them, I was amazed at how accurately they still work even today without any modern equipment.
What I really enjoyed was walking among these unique monuments and seeing how science, architecture, and art blend seamlessly. The guides available at the site explain the purpose of each instrument, which makes the visit much more engaging. I would strongly recommend taking a guided tour to truly appreciate the genius behind the structures.
The place is also well-maintained and offers great spots for photography, especially if you love capturing heritage and geometric patterns. Despite being centuries old, the instruments still inspire curiosity and wonder.
Overall, visiting Jantar Mantar felt like stepping into a living science textbook, where history and innovation come alive. It is not just a monument, but a celebration of human intellect, and a must-visit for anyone exploring Delhi/Jaipur.

Jantar Mantar in Delhi is a historic astronomical observatory built in 1724 by Maharaja Jai Singh II of Jaipur. It consists of 13 large stone instruments designed to measure time, track celestial bodies, and predict astronomical events with the naked eye. Located near Connaught Place, it was created to improve the accuracy of calendars and planetary movement predictions in the 18th century. The observatory showcases India's rich scientific heritage and ancient knowledge of astronomy, with notable instruments such as the huge sundial Samrat Yantra. It is a popular tourist spot, open from 6 AM to 6 PM daily, and easily accessible by metro. The name "Jantar Mantar" means "instrument for calculation" in Sanskrit.

Address: Sansad Marg, near Connaught Place, New Delhi
Entry Fee: ‚Çπ15 for Indians, ‚Çπ200 for foreigners.

Jantar Mantar offers a fascinating glimpse into India's past scientific achievements and is a must-visit for history and astronomy enthusiasts.

Overview
Jantar Mantar in New Delhi is an astronomical observatory built in the 18th century. It is a testament to the scientific and architectural ingenuity of the past, consisting of a collection of colossal masonry instruments used for astronomical observations. It's one of five such observatories built by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II of Jaipur, who was a passionate astronomer and a patron of science. While it may not serve its original scientific purpose today due to the surrounding tall buildings, it remains a fascinating historical and architectural site.
Historical Significance
The Delhi Jantar Mantar was the first of five observatories constructed by Maharaja Jai Singh II between 1724 and 1730, with the others located in Jaipur, Ujjain, Varanasi, and Mathura. He was commissioned by Mughal emperor Muhammad Shah to revise the astronomical tables of the time and improve the accuracy of the calendar. Jai Singh II believed that the smaller, brass instruments used by astronomers were not precise enough, so he built these large, fixed masonry instruments to achieve greater accuracy. The name "Jantar Mantar" is derived from Sanskrit, with "Yantra" meaning instrument and "Mantra" meaning formula or calculation, effectively translating to "instruments for measuring the harmony of the heavens."
Architecture and Instruments
The architecture of Jantar Mantar is striking, with its geometric, sculpture-like instruments that are both functional and visually impressive. The complex is an open-air observatory with several key instruments, each designed for a specific astronomical purpose.
* Samrat Yantra: This is the most prominent instrument, a massive triangular sundial (the "Supreme Instrument"). It was used to measure time with remarkable accuracy, with a large gnomon (the arm of the sundial) and a curved scale on which the shadow would fall.
* Mishra Yantra: This "mixed instrument" is a combination of five instruments and was used to determine the shortest and longest days of the year. It could also be used to find out the precise time of noon in different cities around the world.
* Ram Yantra: Two large cylindrical structures with open tops, designed for measuring the altitude and azimuth of celestial bodies.
* Jai Prakash Yantra: A pair of concave hemispherical sundials used to align the position of stars to markings on the instrument's surface.
Visitor Experience and Review
Jantar Mantar offers a unique experience for visitors, blending science, history, and art.
* Atmosphere: The site is a tranquil green space in the middle of a bustling city, offering a peaceful environment for exploration. The instruments themselves have a sculptural quality that is very appealing.
* Educational Value: For those interested in astronomy and ancient science, the complex is an educational marvel. It provides a tangible glimpse into the scientific knowledge and dedication of 18th-century Indian astronomers. Guides (sometimes available) or informational plaques can help explain the function of each instrument.
* Photography: The striking shapes and colors of the instruments against the backdrop of the sky make Jantar Mantar a popular spot for photographers.
* Accessibility: Jantar Mantar is located on Sansad Marg near Connaught Place, making it easily accessible by Delhi Metro (the nearest station is Patel Chowk or Rajiv Chowk). Entry fees are low for Indian citizens and a bit higher for foreigners.
In summary, Jantar Mantar is a compelling destination for anyone with an interest in history, science, and unique architecture. While its functionality has been compromised by modern buildings, its historical significance and the sheer brilliance of its design make it a worthwhile visit for a glimpse into India's rich scientific past.

Jantar Mantar in Delhi is an extraordinary observatory constructed by Maharaja Jai Singh II. It stands as a testament to the scientific and astronomical genius of 18th-century India. The complex, consisting of monumental instruments, was built with the purpose of compiling accurate astronomical tables and predicting the movements of celestial bodies, showcasing a sophisticated understanding of the cosmos long before modern technology.
‚ÄãThe observatory's key instruments, like the massive Samrat Yantra (Supreme Instrument), function as an enormous sundial, capable of measuring time with impressive accuracy. The Jai Prakash Yantra, or "light of victory," is another unique design, consisting of hollowed hemispheres used to observe the position of the sun. These structures, along with others, were meticulously designed to track the sun, moon, and planets.
‚ÄãFor the modern tourist, Jantar Mantar is more than just a collection of old buildings; it's an immersive experience. The sheer scale and architectural beauty of the instruments are breathtaking. You can walk among these large, geometric forms, marveling at how they were engineered to perform complex calculations. It offers a tangible connection to history and a sense of wonder at the ingenuity of ancient astronomers.
‚ÄãVisiting Jantar Mantar provides valuable insights into India's rich scientific heritage. It‚Äôs a perfect spot for anyone interested in science, history, or simply looking for a peaceful and visually stunning place to explore. It‚Äôs an educational and inspiring journey that highlights the timeless human pursuit of understanding our place in the universe.

The Lotus Temple is one of the most peaceful and beautiful places in Delhi. The architecture is stunning‚Äîit really does look like a blooming lotus surrounded by water ponds. The best part is the calm and serene atmosphere inside the prayer hall, where people of all religions can sit quietly and meditate. Entry is free, but it‚Äôs best to visit early in the morning or in the evening to avoid the heavy crowds and heat. Photography is allowed outside but not inside the prayer hall. Overall, it‚Äôs a must-visit landmark if you‚Äôre in Delhi, not just for the architecture but also for the unique sense of peace you feel here.

The Lotus Temple, located in New Delhi, India, is a stunning Baha'i House of Worship known for its unique lotus flower-inspired architecture. Completed in 1986, the temple features 27 marble-clad petals arranged in clusters of three, creating a breathtaking sight. The temple is open to people of all faiths and backgrounds, serving as a place of worship and contemplation. Its serene ambiance and beautiful gardens make it a popular tourist destination. The Lotus Temple symbolizes unity, peace, and spirituality, welcoming visitors from around the world. Its design has earned numerous accolades, and it has become an iconic symbol of India's rich cultural diversity. Visitors can explore the temple grounds, learn about the Baha'i faith, and experience a sense of tranquility amidst the bustling city. The Lotus Temple is a must-visit destination for those seeking spiritual enlightenment and architectural marvels.

Today, I visited the Lotus Temple in Delhi on my own, and although it wasn‚Äôt my first time, the experience was still special in its own way. The temple is one of the most iconic landmarks in Delhi, known for its serene ambiance and its breathtaking lotus-shaped architecture.

Unfortunately, just as I arrived, it started raining heavily, which meant I couldn‚Äôt actually enter the temple. This was my second attempt at visiting, and yet again, I had to admire it mostly from the outside. Despite that, the overall experience was memorable.

The Lotus Temple‚Äôs design is truly a sight to behold. The white marble petals form a giant lotus, symbolizing purity, peace, and unity. Even from a distance, the temple exudes a sense of calm. Surrounded by lush green gardens, the area feels like a peaceful escape from Delhi‚Äôs chaos. Standing there in the light rain, looking at the temple with droplets shimmering on the white marble, was almost meditative.

While I couldn‚Äôt step inside this time, I still cherish the quietness and the spiritual vibe that the place radiates. I also appreciated how clean and well-maintained the premises are. The sound of rain on the leaves and pathways only made the experience more soothing.

If I had to sum it up:

Pros: Stunning architecture, peaceful surroundings, serene atmosphere

Cons: Entry can be restricted during rain, so plan accordingly

Even though I haven‚Äôt yet fully explored the temple from the inside, I still find myself drawn to its energy. My love for this place grows with each visit, and I hope that on my third visit, I finally get to sit inside and experience the silence and tranquility that the Lotus Temple is famous for.

Tibet House in Delhi is a cultural gem that beautifully showcases Tibetan art, culture, and heritage. As a traveler, stepping into Tibet House feels like entering a serene sanctuary that preserves the rich traditions of Tibet. The museum exhibits captivating artifacts, traditional artworks, and glimpses into the history of Tibetan Buddhism.

Attending events and talks organized by Tibet House provides unique insights into Tibetan culture. The ambiance and the collection make it a must-visit destination for anyone seeking to explore the depth and beauty of Tibetan heritage while in Delhi.

Tibet House in New Delhi is a cultural center and institution with a unique focus on Tibetan heritage, culture, and spirituality. Established to preserve and promote Tibetan culture, it serves as a repository of Tibetan artifacts, manuscripts, and artworks, making it a significant institution for those interested in Tibetan history and Buddhism.

Visitors to Tibet House can explore exhibitions showcasing Tibetan art, thangkas (traditional Tibetan scroll paintings), sculptures, and historical artifacts. The center also hosts cultural events, workshops, lectures, and discussions related to Tibetan culture and Buddhism. It provides a platform for understanding the rich and diverse traditions of Tibetan Buddhism and the unique cultural heritage of Tibet.

Moreover, Tibet House plays a pivotal role in creating awareness about the Tibetan cause and the situation in Tibet. It often hosts talks and events related to the Tibetan diaspora and the political and social issues facing Tibetans in exile.

For anyone interested in Tibetan culture, history, or Buddhism, Tibet House in New Delhi is an excellent place to gain insights and engage with the vibrant Tibetan community in India. It offers a meaningful and educational experience in a peaceful setting.

I recently had the pleasure of visiting Tibet House, the Cultural Centre of His Holiness the Dalai Lama in New Delhi, and it was an experience I will cherish for a lifetime. As soon as I stepped inside the premises, I was immediately struck by the serene ambiance and the rich cultural heritage that permeated every corner.

The staff at Tibet House were incredibly warm and welcoming, making me feel right at home. They were knowledgeable and passionate about Tibetan culture, and their enthusiasm was infectious. They guided me through the various exhibits, providing detailed explanations about the artifacts, artworks, and historical relics on display.

The museum section of Tibet House was an absolute treasure trove of Tibetan history and tradition. The carefully curated collection showcased the remarkable journey of the Tibetan people, their struggles, and their resilience. From ancient manuscripts to intricately woven thangka paintings, each exhibit transported me to a different era, enabling me to gain a deeper understanding of Tibetan Buddhism and its profound influence on Tibetan society.

The library at Tibet House was a haven for book lovers and researchers alike. It housed an extensive collection of texts, rare manuscripts, and scholarly works on Tibetan philosophy, art, and literature. Spending time in this serene space, surrounded by shelves upon shelves of knowledge, was a true delight.

One highlight of my visit was attending a cultural event at the auditorium. The performances by Tibetan artists were mesmerizing, showcasing traditional music, dance, and even theater. It was a rare opportunity to witness the vibrant Tibetan arts firsthand and be captivated by the sheer talent and grace of the performers.

The caf√© at Tibet House was a cozy spot where I could relax and reflect on the profound experience I had just encountered. The menu featured a variety of Tibetan delicacies, allowing me to savor the authentic flavors of Tibet. The momos, in particular, were simply divine and left me craving for more.

Overall, my visit to Tibet House was an immersive and enlightening experience. It is more than just a cultural center; it is a sanctuary that preserves and celebrates the rich heritage of Tibet. Whether you are a history enthusiast, a seeker of spiritual knowledge, or simply curious about different cultures, Tibet House is a must-visit destination in New Delhi. It offers a unique opportunity to connect with the essence of Tibetan culture, and I highly recommend it to anyone seeking a meaningful and transformative experience.

Note: This review is based on my personal experience and reflects my honest opinion of Tibet House, Cultural Centre of His Holiness the Dalai Lama in New Delhi.

placeMetadata.name: Rashtrapati Bhavan

sources.snippet: Rashtrapati Bhavan, the official residence of the President of India, is a prominent historical landmark in Delhi. Designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens, it stands as an architectural masterpiece and is one of the iconic historical places in Delhi. The sprawling estate and grandeur of Rashtrapati Bhavan reflect India's colonial and post-independence history.
sources.shortName: 30 Historical Places In Delhi For A Heritage Tour 2024
12 famous buildings in India: From ancient wonders to modern marvels

placeMetadata.description: Official residence plus Mughal and herbal gardens of the President of India, with visits by request.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Rashtrapati Bhavan, the official residence of the President of India, is a must-visit for every Indian. The grand estate includes elegant Mughal gardens and a newly inaugurated museum showcasing its rich history. Built between 1912 and 1929, this 340-room building served as the British Viceroys House before India gained independence. Its architecture reflects a blend of Indo-Saracenic, Mauryan, Mughal, and regional styles.
placeMetadata.address: Rashtrapati Bhawan, President's Estate, New Delhi, Delhi 110004, India

reviews.reviewText:
Visiting Rashtrapati Bhawan is a fascinating experience, offering a glimpse into India‚Äôs rich heritage and governance. The grand architecture, well-maintained Mughal Gardens, and the informative museum provide deep insights into the country‚Äôs history. The guided tour is well-organized, allowing visitors to explore the majestic halls and learn about the President‚Äôs residence. Overall, it‚Äôs a memorable visit, showcasing both grandeur and historical significance.

Must-visit place, Prior booking is required.
Phone and bags  are not allowed inside need to submit at reception area.

This place will make you feel proud and privileged. The area is vast, filled with greenery, and everything is well maintained. Inside the building, only a few areas are accessible, and only with a guide. Our guide was knowledgeable, but she spoke in a low voice‚Äîperhaps due to illness or a health issue. It would be helpful if the authorities provided guides with a speaker, so everyone could hear clearly.

It is essential to book your visit online. Tickets may be available on the spot, but that depends on availability. Carrying a valid identity card is a must. Foreigners are allowed to visit this place.

A must-visit! Rashtrapati Bhavan is definitely worth the trip. It's a truly enriching experience, especially with the knowledgeable free guides who explain everything so well.

A few tips for your visit: you need to book your slot online, which costs 50Rs. It's best to plan for a morning slot around 9:30 am to avoid delays. Be mindful of their security rules: only a small ladies' handbag is allowed. All other bags and electronic items must be submitted at the reception counter after you've registered.

Remember to double-check the proper gate number for your entry to ensure a smooth visit. Highly recommended!

A must visit, at least once in your life. Take your whole family. The tickets are easily available online. The compound is amazing. The whole tour takes less than 20 minutes but the wait before starting can be almost an hour.
Reach just 10 minutes before your slot.
Avoid taking bags or anything extra.

What an electrifying experience! üáÆüá≥ The Change of Guard ceremony is a spectacle that stirs the soul ‚Äì a delightful blend of precision, pride, and pageantry that's utterly captivating!

- *Presidential Bodyguard Parade*: Witnessing the impeccable drill of the presidential bodyguards is like stepping into a vortex of discipline and grandeur. Their movements are poetry in motion ‚Äì sharp, synchronized, and dripping with tradition.
- Evokes Republic Day Vibes: It transports you straight to the patriotic fervor of January 26, Republic Day parade ‚Äì that same spirit of national pride swirls palpably through the air.
- Front-row Seating Magic: Booking a spot right at the front via online booking for the Saturday shows puts you at the heart of the action! You feel immersed, like you're part of an exclusive, thrilling tableau vivant.
- *Saturday Spectacle*: Every Saturday morning at 7am, this ceremony unfolds with pomp ‚Äì an experience begging to be savored, etched with the rich heritage of India's military traditions.

It's an encounter with tradition, pride, and spectacle ‚Äì leaving you with memories stamped in vivid colors! üåü Would you want to witness this majestic ceremony, soaking in the pride and pageantry?

Amrit Udyan at Rashtrapati Bhavan is one of the most beautiful gardens I have ever visited. The variety of flowers, especially roses, tulips, and seasonal blooms, are arranged so artistically that every corner feels like a painting. The fountains, greenery, and perfectly maintained lawns add to the charm. The ambience is calm and refreshing, making it an ideal spot for nature lovers, families, and photography enthusiasts. The arrangements for visitors are well managed, with proper entry, security, and facilities. Visiting during the annual opening season is truly a magical experience ‚Äî a blend of heritage, beauty, and serenity.

I recently got the chance to visit Rashtrapati Bhavan in Delhi all by myself, and it turned out to be one of the most fascinating solo experiences I‚Äôve had. Being the official residence of the President of India, the place already carries a sense of grandeur, but seeing it in person was something else entirely.

The first thing that struck me was the massive scale of the building. Designed by Edwin Lutyens, its architecture blends Indian and European styles beautifully. Walking along the pathways, I couldn‚Äôt help but admire the perfectly maintained lawns and the symmetrical structure of the building. The iconic dome stood tall and impressive, making me pause just to take it all in.

I also got to explore the Mughal Gardens (now called Amrit Udyan), which were absolutely stunning. The colorful flowers, fountains, and neatly trimmed hedges made the place feel almost dreamlike. Sitting alone on a bench there gave me a rare moment of calm right in the heart of Delhi.

Since I went alone, I could move at my own pace‚Äîreading little details, taking photos, and just observing the surroundings without distraction. Security was understandably tight, but everything was organized well, making the visit smooth.

What I liked most was the mix of history, architecture, and serenity that Rashtrapati Bhavan offers. It‚Äôs not just a building; it‚Äôs a symbol of India‚Äôs heritage and democracy. Visiting it solo gave me the chance to truly appreciate its grandeur and peaceful atmosphere.

People generally review Rashtrapati Bhavan positively, praising its architectural beauty, historical significance, and the Mughal Gardens. Visitors highlight the importance of guided tours for understanding the site's history, while some point out areas for improvement, such as online ticketing, better shops, and clearer signage. The museum and stables are also noted for their collections of gifts and historical artifacts, though some find the process of visiting could be more professional and the museum better maintained.
Positive Aspects
Architecture and History:
Visitors consistently praise the architectural marvel of the building and its deep connection to Indian history.
Mughal Gardens:
The gardens are a highlight, with visitors appreciating their vibrant floral displays and serene ambiance.
Guided Tours:
Guided tours are frequently recommended, with staff providing valuable information and helping visitors understand the intricate details of the building and its history.
Museum Complex:
The museum is noted for its fascinating collection of gifts and technology used for display, offering a deep dive into the lives of India's presidents.
Areas for Improvement
Ticketing:
Some users have difficulty booking tickets online, especially with international credit cards.
Amenities:
Visitors suggest improving the quality of items sold in shops, the external canteen, and the availability of card payment options.
Staff & Maintenance:
Some reviews mention a need for more professional administrative staff and better maintenance of the museum.
Navigation:
There are suggestions that the site's location is not always clear to taxi drivers, making it difficult to find.
Tips for Visitors
Pre-book your visit:
It is advised to book online in advance and arrive on time for the tour.
Take the guided tour:
This is considered a great way to understand the history and significance of the site.
Explore at your own pace:
While guided tours are good, take time to explore the museum and exhibits on your own.
Consider off-season visits:
Some areas might be under renovation, so it can be worthwhile to plan your visit for a time when renovations are complete.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: India Gate, located at the eastern end of Raj Path in New Delhi, is a grand triumphal arch that serves as a war memorial for Indian soldiers who lost their lives in World War I. Designed by renowned architect Edward Lutyens and inaugurated in 1921, it commemorates over 70,000 Indian soldiers who perished during the war. The monument also honors more than 13,500 British and Indian soldiers killed in the Afghan war of 1919.

Isa Khan‚Äôs Tomb is a hidden gem in Delhi, offering a peaceful and serene atmosphere that‚Äôs perfect for those seeking solitude and connection with nature. Tucked away from the city‚Äôs busy streets, this place provides a quiet escape where you can truly unwind and be present with yourself.

Surrounded by greenery and calmness, the tomb is set in a nature-rich environment that invites slow walks, gentle reflection, and peaceful moments. It‚Äôs not just a historical site‚Äîit‚Äôs a sanctuary where time seems to slow down. The silence here is soothing, broken only by the soft rustling of leaves or birdsong, making it an ideal place to spend time in sanity and mindfulness.

Unlike many other crowded tourist spots, Usha Khan‚Äôs Tomb offers space to breathe and reflect without distractions. Whether you‚Äôre looking for a quiet afternoon to clear your mind or a simple place to sit and journal, this site creates the perfect backdrop.

For anyone in search of peace, nature, and a break from the chaos of daily life, this is one of the best spots in the city. Isa  Khan‚Äôs Tomb is not just a visit‚Äîit‚Äôs a moment of stillness you‚Äôll be grateful for.

Tucked away within the Humayun‚Äôs Tomb complex, Isa Khan‚Äôs Tomb is often overlooked ‚Äî but absolutely worth a visit.  The octagonal tomb, surrounded by a beautiful garden and arched verandahs, has a distinct character compared to the more grand Mughal structures nearby. Its simplicity, symmetry, and detailed latticework reflect a different era of design ‚Äî and it‚Äôs remarkably well-preserved.

While not as majestic as Humayun‚Äôs Tomb, the peaceful setting and fewer crowds make it a great spot for quiet reflection and photography.

The Isa Khan Tomb Complex is a beautiful and historical site located in Delhi, near the famous Humayun‚Äôs Tomb. This complex is not only a fine example of early Mughal architecture but also a peaceful and well-maintained heritage place that takes you back in time. Isa Khan Niazi, whose tomb is at the centre of the complex, was a noble in the court of Sher Shah Suri, and his tomb was built in the year 1547, much before Humayun‚Äôs Tomb.
The tomb is built in Afghan-style architecture and has a unique octagonal shape, surrounded by a lovely garden enclosed within high walls. The detailed stone lattice work (jaali), beautiful arches, and the red and grey sandstone make the structure look very elegant and artistic. Inside, the tomb is simple but peaceful, and the dome above adds to the charm of the structure.
Apart from the main tomb, the complex also has a mosque and remains of other old structures. The mosque has three arches and a large dome, and is also built in traditional Mughal style. What makes this place special is its calm atmosphere, clean surroundings, and greenery. It is a less crowded spot compared to other monuments in Delhi, which makes it a perfect place for visitors who want to explore history peacefully.
The Archaeological Survey of India has done a good job in restoring the site and keeping it clean. Overall, the Isa Khan Tomb Complex is a hidden gem for history lovers, architecture students, and tourists who want to see the roots of Mughal design and enjoy some quiet time in a historical setting.

The surrounding enclosure adds a layer of serenity and old-world charm. If you‚Äôre in Delhi exploring Mughal heritage, don‚Äôt skip this underrated masterpiece.

I recently explored the Mehrauli Archaeological Park alone, and it turned out to be a wonderful mix of history, peace, and discovery. Spread across a huge area right next to Qutub Minar, the park is filled with ancient monuments, tombs, and ruins that make you feel like you‚Äôve stepped back in time.

Walking in, I was amazed at how quiet and green the place was compared to the busy streets outside. Since I went alone, I could just wander at my own pace, taking random paths and stumbling upon old structures. From the stepwell (Rajon ki Baoli) to historic tombs like Jamali Kamali, every spot had its own charm. The carvings, arches, and weathered stones told silent stories of centuries gone by.

What I liked most was the combination of nature and history. Birds, trees, and wide open spaces made it feel more like a peaceful retreat than a typical tourist site. At some places, I was the only one around, which added a sense of calm and gave me time to sit quietly, click pictures, and just imagine how life must have been here hundreds of years ago.

The park isn‚Äôt as crowded as other monuments, so it‚Äôs perfect for a solo outing if you want both space and history. Of course, it‚Äôs good to carry water and wear comfortable shoes since there‚Äôs a lot of walking. Overall, my solo visit to Mehrauli Archaeological Park was refreshing‚Äîa hidden gem where Delhi‚Äôs history and nature meet beautifully.

Mehrauli Archaeological Park is a hidden jewel‚Äîvalued for its layered history, vast greenery, and quiet ambiance. It's ideal for exploring heritage without the typical touristic crowds.

Plan 3‚Äì5 hours, especially if you want to explore remote corners and stepwells (which are off the main trail) Minimal crowds compared to other Delhi landmarks; photo-friendly and tranquil.

Serene, shaded gardens and trails perfect for walking or relaxingthe park‚Äôs calm and green atmosphere‚Äîa rare oasis of nature in the city. You‚Äôll spot birds, squirrels, shady trails, and occasional fountains, which offer nice photo opportunities at sunset or morning light.

Spread across approximately 200 acres, Mehrauli Archaeological Park is adjacent to the Qutub Minar complex and houses over 100 monuments spanning nearly a millennium‚Äîfrom the Tomar, Khalji, Tughlaq, Lodi, Mughal, to British eras .
If the weather is good, just go to this place and experience amazing architecture of mughal era and learn less known facts. The cafe (Stone cafe) is also nice next to a small pond.

Fatehpuri Masjid has witnessed significant historical events, including the Sepoy Mutiny of 1857. The mosque was even sold to a Hindu merchant, Lala Channa Mal, during the British era but was later returned to the Muslim community in 1877.

Fatehpuri Masjid, one of Delhi‚Äôs oldest and most revered mosques, was constructed in 1650 by Fatehpuri Begum, a wife of the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan, who also commissioned the Taj Mahal. Named after its founder, Fatehpuri Masjid stands at the western end of the bustling Chandni Chowk, opposite the monumental Red Fort and facing Jama Masjid across the old city. This masjid showcases the intricate Mughal architectural style, specifically with its red sandstone structure, onion-shaped domes, and beautifully arched gateways.

Architectural Features: Fatehpuri Masjid‚Äôs architecture is modest yet impressive, embodying the classic simplicity of Mughal aesthetics. The mosque features a central courtyard surrounded by arched galleries, with three large domes topping the main prayer hall. The walls are adorned with calligraphic inscriptions, and the traditional mihrab (prayer niche) inside the hall is decorated with minimalistic yet elegant carvings. Unlike the Jama Masjid, Fatehpuri Masjid has a single prayer hall, but its architecture allows ample natural light and ventilation, making it a peaceful and inviting space for worship.

Historical Significance: Fatehpuri Masjid has stood as a silent witness to Delhi‚Äôs transformations, from the grandeur of the Mughal era to British colonial rule and post-independence India. After the First War of Indian Independence in 1857, British forces seized the mosque, converting it into a military base and storehouse as part of a larger effort to suppress the city‚Äôs Muslim community. Subsequently, the British auctioned it to Rai Lala Chunnamal, a prominent local businessman and one of the few wealthy individuals allowed to remain in the Chandni Chowk area after the uprising.

In 1877, in recognition of its religious significance and as a goodwill gesture to the Muslim community, the British returned the masjid to its original purpose through negotiations funded by the Nawab of Rampur, a well-known patron of art, culture, and religious institutions.

Cultural and Religious Role: Over the centuries, Fatehpuri Masjid has served as an essential spiritual and educational center for the Muslim community in Delhi. The masjid houses a madrasa (Islamic school), which has historically attracted students from all over the region. In addition to regular prayers, the masjid is a gathering point for Friday congregational prayers, Eid celebrations, and other significant religious events. The mosque‚Äôs tranquil courtyard provides a place for reflection amidst the surrounding hustle and bustle of Chandni Chowk‚Äôs market streets, drawing not only worshippers but also travelers, photographers, and history enthusiasts.

Present-Day Fatehpuri Masjid: Today, Fatehpuri Masjid remains a well-preserved monument, revered both as a functioning mosque and a historic site. The masjid is managed by the local community, with ongoing efforts to maintain its architectural integrity and spiritual atmosphere. During Ramzan, the masjid comes alive with devotees who gather for iftar and tarawih prayers, creating an atmosphere that resonates with Delhi‚Äôs rich Islamic traditions.

Visitors to Fatehpuri Masjid often enjoy its proximity to the cultural heart of Old Delhi. Surrounded by traditional markets, iconic eateries, and centuries-old shops, the masjid is integral to the living heritage of the area. Fatehpuri Masjid stands as both a piece of Mughal history and a testament to the resilience and continuity of Delhi‚Äôs Islamic culture, drawing visitors who seek a glimpse into the city‚Äôs layered past and its enduring cultural diversity.

Fatehpuri Masjid in Old Delhi is a beautiful and peaceful escape from the bustling streets nearby. The architecture is impressive, showcasing Mughal design with intricate details. It‚Äôs less crowded than Jama Masjid, making it a serene spot to explore and reflect. A must-visit if you‚Äôre in Old Delhi, especially if you appreciate history and architecture!

placeMetadata.name: Jama Masjid

sources.snippet: Considered to be one of the last of the Mughal emperor Shah JahƒÅn‚Äôs vast architectural legacies, the Masjid-i-Jahan Numa‚Äîmeaning ‚Äúmosque commanding a view of the world‚Äù and popularly known as the Jama Masjid‚Äîis one of India‚Äôs largest and most revered mosques. It was constructed in 1650‚Äì56 in the Mughal capital of Shahjahanaba (now known as Old Delhi) opposite the emperor‚Äôs home, the Lal Quila (Red Fort). The royal residence had no private place of prayer, and the construction of the mosque beyond its walls was a symbol that the city outside the fort was not deprived of royal patronage.

sources.snippet: With minarets on all four sides that reach the skies, Jama Masjid, Emperor Shah Jahan‚Äôs last architectural indulgence, was commissioned in 1650 and took six years to be built. Statesman House, located in Connaught Place (CP),

New Delhi, India, is a commercial building known for its association with "The Statesman" newspaper.

It is situated in a prime location with convenient connectivity to major micro-markets in Delhi NCR through road and metro networks.

Within a 2 km radius, you can find upscale 5-star hotels and hospitals.

Designed by renowned architects Herbert Baker and Edwin Lutyens in 2001, Statesman House stands in contrast to their usual classic bungalow style.

The building's architecture deviates from their traditional designs, reflecting a more contemporary approach.

Connaught Place, where Statesman House is situated, is a bustling commercial hub characterized by its circular layout and colonial-era architecture.

It is home to various offices, shops, restaurants, and cultural venues. The area attracts both locals and tourists, offering a vibrant and lively atmosphere.

With its central location, Statesman House enjoys excellent connectivity to different parts of Delhi through the well-established road and metro networks.

Visitors can easily access other major micro-markets in the National Capital Region (NCR) using these transportation options.

In summary, Statesman House is a commercial building in Connaught Place, Delhi, housing "The Statesman" newspaper.

It offers good connectivity to major micro-markets, has 5-star hotels and hospitals nearby,

sources.snippet: A counterpart reflection of the NCDC building; this one is the later example of an exposed concrete structure, as both being designed by the same architect. An expressive concrete structure with a curved base, the NCDC building, adds up to the list of brutalist structures in Delhi that have been an integral part of the memories of every Delhiite who witnessed the post-independence period with uttermost love and affection for its new nation. Another unifying thread between quite a few of these buildings, including Akbar Hotel, Shri Ram Centre, and the Hall of Nations, is the structural engineer associated with all of them: Mahendra Raj, also deserves the credit for the designs of these memorials.
sources.shortName: First face of Brutalist Architecture in India -

sources.snippet: These are two later examples of exposed concrete structures in the city, and among the better maintained. Palika Kendra on Parliament Street is a soaring, expressive concrete structure with a curved base, and the NCDC building on Khel Gaon Marg is a quirky stepped-pyramid building. A unifying thread connecting these two buildings, as well as Akbar Hotel, Sriram Center and the Hall of Nations, is the structural engineer associated with all of them: Mahendra Raj, who deserves much credit for the design of these structures.

*Academics*
IIT Delhi offers various undergraduate and postgraduate courses, including B.Tech, M.Tech, B.Des, MBA, M.Des, (link unavailable), PhD, and PG Diploma . Admission to B.Tech programs is based on JEE Advanced, followed by JOSAA counseling, while M.Tech admission requires GATE scores, COAP counseling, and a written test/interview.

*Infrastructure and Facilities*
The institute boasts modern infrastructure, including well-equipped classrooms, laboratories, and research facilities. Students have access to high-speed internet, spacious classrooms, and state-of-the-art labs for various engineering disciplines .

*Placements*
IIT Delhi offers excellent placement opportunities, with top recruiters like E&Y, CYENT, Nvidia, CISCO, Genpact, and Amazon . The placement percentage is around 86.11%, with a median salary of ‚Çπ20 lakh.

*Student Life*
Life at IIT Delhi is vibrant, with various cultural and technical festivals, events, and informal gatherings. Students can participate in clubs and extracurricular activities, such as robotics, coding, literature, music, and dance.

*Scholarships*
IIT Delhi provides scholarships to students based on merit and need, including Merit-cum-Means (MCM) scholarships, Institute Merit Prizes, and Donor Scholarships . SC/ST/PwD students are exempt from tuition fees, and PhD students receive financial assistance through Teaching/Research Assistantship.

Overall, IIT Delhi is a great institution for students seeking excellent academics, research opportunities, and placements.

reviews.reviewText:
We approached AKDA with a single constraint/requirement that the cost of construction should  be kept as low as possible since we were on a shoe string budget. We could not even fathom at that time that beautiful yet functional design and cost need not be mutually exclusive. Steve Jobs famously said "A lot of times, people don't know what they want until you show it to them.‚Äù With AKDA we had the opportunity to experience this first hand.

What followed after just a few meetings was a house designed with not just the residents in mind but also the environment. AKDA had managed to give us decent sized bedrooms, a fabulous living space and a green backyard that also made use of the existing tree and added to the charm of the house. With a huge angled glass window in the front, they were also able to utilize the view of the park from our plot. The view of serene greenery and open spaces made us realize that we had not and would not have thought of these as top priority requirements/needs in the house. It was hard to imagine that a simple rectilinear plot of land surrounded by houses on all sides could feel so pleasant, airy and spacious. Put simply, we don‚Äôt need a holiday home.

By managing and executing the construction through their own team, AKDA managed all this while keeping our construction costs within an unheard range of Rs. 1000/sq foot. To top it off, our house has already been featured in some of the top architecture publications around the world. As a home-owner, that gives us the feeling that we own a piece of history and possibly one of the finest houses in the area.

Absolutely horrible experience speaking to them on call. They said - QUOTE - WE DO NOT TAKE UP PROJECTS THAT DO NOT HAVE AN ARCHITECTURAL EDGE TO THEM. The girl I spoke to couldn't come up with a justified excuse and kept mumbling vain excuses like we do not do projects outside delhi which they clearly do, and we do not do particular plot sizes which again they clearly do. Not sure how many problems I would have had to face just in case I hired them. Unreasonable untrained noob architects.

I hired Amit to design a house that I was building for myself. Actually I should rather say that Amit hired himself for the project elbowing me out (I am an architect myself). I guess he wanted to do a design exercise in which he had a design appreciative client, (yours truly) and in which the boundaries could be stretched in pursuit of an idea with a slight disregard to mundane worldly requirements. In fact this could also be an exercise to see if these mundane worldly requirements actually amount to much.

So, we began the process of design and construction in which he came up with a really unique scheme. We also devised a few new construction methods (shallow excavation ) that proved fruitful. Testament to that is the fact that the building is still standing and due to be occupied very shortly.

Time to talk about Amit. If I could put it very concisely I would say that Amit is someone who does not have to be told to be truthful to his work. He does not cut corners, He is not lazy, He is honest and he is all these things because of his inner drive.

So in case you hire him you are free of doubt as to the professionalism that he brings. you can be sure that he will do his job with the minimum of fuss and maximum dedication and you will not have to drive him to do it. And that's what you hire professionals for, isn't it?

Akshardham Temple is stunning with its grand architecture and peaceful atmosphere. The carvings are beautiful, the gardens are well maintained, and the evening water show is a must-watch. Phones and cameras aren‚Äôt allowed inside, but the experience is unforgettable.

July 5, 2025 ‚Äì 2nd day in Delhi

Our tour guide brought us to Akshardham, a grand Hindu spiritual and cultural complex known for its stunning architecture and peaceful atmosphere. I had heard so much about it and was glad to finally see it in person.

We left all our belongings‚Äîincluding phones, cameras, and bags‚Äîin the car, as absolutely no electronics are allowed inside. The rules are very strict, and there are multiple security checks. While I understand the need for security, the staff at the entry checkpoints came across as quite rude. The pat downs felt unnecessarily rough, which made the start of our visit a bit uncomfortable.

The structures themselves are breathtaking. The intricate carvings, massive domes, and the scale of the complex are truly impressive. It‚Äôs clear that an incredible amount of work and devotion went into creating this space. But it was extremely crowded, and the overwhelming number of people made it hard to enjoy the beauty. At times it felt almost suffocating, especially under the intense afternoon heat.

My five and seven year old were just not able to take much from the experience. Even though I pointed out the beautiful details and architecture, they were too hot and tired to engage. We had looked forward to exploring the grounds more, but between the crowd and the heat, we had to cut it short.

There are definitely peaceful corners here‚Äîfountains, gardens, and shaded walkways‚Äîbut overall, the experience felt more hectic than calming. I can see how it could be meaningful on a cooler, quieter day, but for us, it was a bit too much.

Beautifully well maintained..spiritual cultural place.Electronic items are not allowed inside. We can have the locker facility. The structure and the intricate carving is wonderfully done. Clean , well maintained, peaceful place.

placeMetadata.name: Qutb Minar

sources.snippet: Qutub Minar and Complex, located in Delhi, stands as one of the iconic historical places in the city. The centerpiece, Qutub Minar, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and the world's tallest brick minaret, showcasing exquisite Islamic architecture. The complex encompasses various historically significant structures, such as the Iron Pillar of Delhi, making it a must-visit destination for those exploring the rich history of Delhi.
sources.shortName: 30 Historical Places In Delhi For A Heritage Tour 2024

placeMetadata.description: 73m tapering tower built in 1193 by Qutab-ud-din Aibak after defeat of Delhi's last Hindu kingdom.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Qutub Minar, located in Delhi, is a 73-meter tall victory tower and minaret built in 1193 by Sultan Qutb-ud-din Aibak to signify his dominance over the defeated Hindu rulers. The complex also includes the Iron Pillar of Delhi and other historically significant structures. This UNESCO World Heritage Site showcases exquisite Islamic architecture and is considered one of the most important places to visit in Delhi.

Qutub Minar is a stunning symbol of Delhi‚Äôs rich history and timeless architecture.

Perfect spot for history lovers, photographers, and peaceful walks.
Truly a must-visit heritage site that takes you back in time. üåÖ

An incredible historical monument with stunning architecture and rich heritage. The intricate carvings and towering presence of Qutub Minar are truly mesmerizing. The surrounding complex is well-maintained and offers a peaceful walk through history. A must-visit in Delhi!

We visited Qutb Minar on Independence Day, and it was very crowded. There was a long queue at both the ticket counter and the entry gate. It‚Äôs better to book tickets online, as it will make the entry process easier. Visit this place if you‚Äôre interested in historical sites.

Qutub Minar is a must-visit historical monument with stunning architecture and a serene vibe. The place is very clean and extremely well-maintained, which really enhances the overall experience.

You do need to buy an entry ticket, but I visited on World Heritage Day, so the entry was free. Normally, tickets can be purchased online or at the counter.

If you're visiting during summer, I highly recommend carrying a hat, an umbrella, and a bottle of water. It gets quite hot, and there are very few shaded areas to rest. Keep in mind, you won‚Äôt find anything to eat or drink inside the monument premises. However, just outside the entrance, there are plenty of eateries, street food stalls, and small shops.

Qutub Minar is just about 2 km from the nearest metro station (Qutub Minar Metro Station). Autos are easily available, and they usually charge ‚Çπ20 per person for a ride to the monument and the same for the return trip.

One thing to note‚Äîsome auto drivers might offer to take you to a nearby shopping center called "Rajasthan Textile Development Corporation" by saying there‚Äôs no waiting charge. This is because they get commissions based on how long you stay at the shop, so keep that in mind if you're short on time or uninterested in shopping.

Overall, it‚Äôs a beautiful place to soak in history, architecture, and calm vibes‚Äîjust plan well if you're going in the summer!

My experience here was absolutely amazing. The minar itself is so intricate and beautiful, and the other tombs are also good to visit.

Qutub Minar provides a unique insight into the architectural journey of India, reflecting a seamless fusion of Islamic and Hindu artistic traditions. The monument‚Äôs impressive height, detailed engravings, and ancient script work speak to the intellectual vision of its builders. Beyond being a historical structure, the encompassing archaeological site enriches the visit, making it a profound cultural and artistic experience. Standing in its shadow, one feels the lasting impact of creative collaboration that defines Delhi‚Äôs historical identity.
