reviews.reviewText:
A Haven of Peace and Harmony

Dargah Hazrat Nizamuddin Aulia

If you find yourself in Delhi, a visit to the Dargah Hazrat Nizamuddin Aulia is an absolute must. This sacred space pulsates with an atmosphere of profound peace, prosperity, love, and happiness that is truly captivating. From the moment you step into the bustling lanes leading to the shrine, you are enveloped in a unique cultural experience that touches your soul.

The air resonates with devotional music (Qawwali), the scent of incense, and the murmur of prayers. It's a place where people from all walks of life, irrespective of their religious beliefs, come together with unwavering faith. Witnessing this unity and devotion is incredibly moving. The architecture, steeped in history, adds to the spiritual ambiance, transporting you to another time.

While the overall experience is deeply enriching, it's wise to be mindful of your surroundings. Like any popular religious site, there can be individuals who may try to exploit the faith of visitors through donation scams. It's best to be cautious and avoid engaging with anyone who approaches you with unsolicited offers for Dargah updates or requests for your personal information. Stick to official donation boxes if you wish to contribute.

Despite this minor caution, the Dargah Hazrat Nizamuddin Aulia remains a powerful and uplifting experience. It's a place where you can find solace, witness the beauty of shared faith, and immerse yourself in a vibrant cultural tapestry. Don't miss the opportunity to experience this spiritual heart of Delhi.

You have to walk through narrow lanes to reach the shrine's gate. Wear sandles and only take off your shoes and sandles near the gate. Shop keepers will call you to take off shoes at their shops , don't; wait till you reach the gate. Inside they will push for donation to four different areas be careful. If visiting for the first time follow regular people and imitate them. You can buy some flowers like me to spread over the shrine.

Hazrat Nizamuddin Auliya was a 13th-century Sufi saint of the Chishti Order, known for his deep spirituality, compassion, and service to humanity. Born in 1238 in Badayun, he lost his father early and moved to Delhi with his mother for education. He became a disciple of Baba Farid and later his spiritual successor.

His khanqah in Delhi became a symbol of love, peace, and equality, welcoming people of all faiths. He preached selflessness, unity, and devotion to God, staying away from politics despite the turbulent times. His teachings were carried forward by his beloved disciple Amir Khusrau.

He passed away in 1325, and his Dargah in Delhi remains a revered spiritual site. His life stands as a beacon of love, humility, and divine service.

Nizamuddin Dargah is a spiritually uplifting and historically significant site nestled in the heart of Delhi. This revered Sufi shrine, dedicated to the 14th-century saint Hazrat Nizamuddin Auliya, attracts devotees from all walks of life, as well as tourists drawn to its rich cultural aura. The atmosphere here is truly soulful ‚Äî the air is filled with the scent of roses and incense, and the rhythmic qawwalis in the evenings evoke a deep sense of peace and devotion.

However, the area can be quite crowded, especially during the evenings and on Thursdays. One must be prepared for narrow lanes and a bit of congestion, especially while approaching the main shrine. A major tip for first-time visitors: do not take off your shoes right at the beginning of the lane. There are shopkeepers who might coax you to leave your footwear early, far from the actual entrance. Instead, walk closer to the Dargah ‚Äî there is a dedicated shop very near the main gate where you can safely and conveniently leave your shoes.

The site offers a mix of architectural beauty and spiritual calm, with intricately designed marble domes, carved pillars, and gold embellishments adding to its charm. While it may lack the modern amenities of more commercialized religious sites, the authenticity and devotion here are unmatched. Whether you're seeking blessings, cultural exploration, or peace of mind, Nizamuddin Dargah offers an experience that lingers long after you leave.

I recently visited Hazrat Nizamuddin Auliya Dargah with my family, and it was a truly peaceful and spiritual experience. If you're seeking inner peace and a deep sense of calm, this is a must-visit place.

Do keep in mind to dress modestly, as it‚Äôs a religious site and should be respected accordingly.

After completing the prayer, if you're a non-veg food lover, I highly recommend visiting Hussaini Hotel, which is just a short walk away. The food there is absolutely delicious ‚Äî full of authentic flavors and worth the wait!

A soulful visit followed by a hearty meal ‚Äî overall, a memorable experience.

Hazrat Nizamuddin Dargah, located in the heart of Delhi, is one of the most revered spiritual destinations in India. Dedicated to the great Sufi saint Hazrat Khwaja Nizamuddin Auliya, the dargah is a serene and soulful place that attracts thousands of visitors daily, regardless of religion or background.

Walking through the narrow, lively lanes toward the dargah, you're immediately immersed in an atmosphere filled with devotion‚Äîfloral vendors, incense, and the soft echo of qawwali music. The dargah itself is beautifully built in Indo-Islamic style, with white marble, intricate carvings, and a calming courtyard.

One of the most captivating experiences here is the live qawwali performance held every Thursday evening. The soulful Sufi music sung in devotion truly elevates the spiritual energy of the place. Many people visit to offer prayers, tie threads for wishes, or simply sit in quiet reflection.

Despite the crowds, the sanctity of the dargah remains untouched. It's a peaceful escape from the chaos of the city. Whether you're spiritual, religious, or simply curious about Delhi‚Äôs culture, a visit to Hazrat Nizamuddin Dargah is a deeply enriching and unforgettable experience.

Tughlaqabad Fort, a 14th-century marvel in Delhi, is a must-visit for history buffs! Built by Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq in 1321, this massive fort with its towering stone walls and 13 remaining gates showcases Tughlaq dynasty architecture. Highlights include the underground passages, rainwater tanks, and the nearby red sandstone mausoleum. The fort‚Äôs rocky hill setting and eerie legend of a Sufi saint‚Äôs curse add mystique, though it was abandoned just six years after construction. Open 7 AM‚Äì5 PM, entry is INR 20 for Indians, INR 200‚Äì250 for foreigners. Easily reachable via Tughlaqabad Metro Station, it‚Äôs a captivating, slightly haunting glimpse into Delhi‚Äôs past. Tughlaqabad Fort is a site that commands respect for its sheer scale and historical significance. Built by Ghiyas-ud-din Tughlaq in the 14th century, the fort's imposing walls and remnants of a once-grand city offer a powerful sense of history. It's a great spot for a peaceful walk, away from the usual chaos of Delhi's more popular monuments. You can spend a good amount of time exploring the vast, sprawling ruins and imagining what the city might have been like in its prime. The views from the top are also quite good, providing a nice panoramic of the surrounding area.
‚ÄãHowever, the experience is decidedly "average" due to its current condition. Much of the fort is in ruins, and not in a well-preserved way.

Recently, I had the opportunity to visit Tughlakabad Fort in New Delhi, and it turned out to be an unforgettable experience that blended history, architecture, and a sense of timeless grandeur.

Built in 1321 by Ghiyas-ud-din Tughlaq, the founder of the Tughlaq dynasty, this fort was envisioned as a stronghold against Mongol invasions. It served both as a fortress and a city, showcasing the ruler‚Äôs ambition and military foresight.

The fort is spread across a massive area, once boasting thick stone walls, massive bastions, and a complex layout that made it nearly impenetrable. Even today, despite being in ruins, the sheer scale and strength of the structure left me in awe.

One fascinating aspect of Tughlakabad‚Äôs history is the curse associated with Saint Nizamuddin Auliya, who allegedly cursed the fort saying "Ya rahe ujjar, ya basey gujjar" ("It will remain deserted or be inhabited by shepherds"). Walking through the ruins, I could feel the eerie, mysterious aura that still lingers.

I was particularly impressed by the monumental gateways, stone corridors, and the remnants of the royal palace and secret passages. Every corner seemed to whisper tales of battles, betrayals, and royal grandeur.

Another highlight of my visit was seeing the Ghiyas-ud-din Tughlaq‚Äôs Tomb, connected to the main fort via a causeway. The tomb, surrounded by gardens, is a beautiful example of Indo-Islamic architecture.

The fort's elevated position gave me panoramic views of the surrounding landscape, and I could easily imagine how this strategic location offered advantages for defense centuries ago.

The experience was a mix of admiration for the architectural brilliance and reflection on how time slowly reclaims even the mightiest of human creations.

I would recommend wearing comfortable shoes, carrying water, and being ready to explore for a few hours, as the fort complex is vast and rugged.

Overall, visiting Tughlakabad Fort was like taking a step back into the 14th century. It deepened my appreciation for Delhi‚Äôs layered history and the incredible stories hidden within its ancient walls.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Purana Qila Museum is a renowned archaeological museum in Delhi, showcasing a vast collection of artifacts from various historical periods. The museum displays findings and artifacts from excavations carried out by the Archaeological Survey of India, including objects dating back to 1000 BC. Located within the Purana Qila complex, the museum offers insights into the history of Delhi, with exhibits spanning from Mauryan to Mughal periods.
placeMetadata.address: J65V+84P, Pragati Maidan, New Delhi, Delhi 110001, India

reviews.reviewText: Archaeological Museum, Purana Qila was established in 1973 CE with the main aim to display the antiquities recovered from the excavation at Purana Qila conducted during 1969 to 1973 CE. The objective of the excavation was to know the ancient history and archaeological remains of Purana Qila. This Museum is situated on the right side of the main entrance gate (Western Darwaza) of the Purana Qila. On the basis of archaeological relics retrieved at the site, it appears that the ancient site of Purana Qila flourished from the Mauryan period to the Early Mughal Period (3rd Century BCE to 16th Century CE). It is believed that there was a distinct settlement of Painted Grey Ware culture dated to circa 1000 BCE since this type of ware has been collected at the site from unstratified levels. The site is also known as Indraprastha. The Epic Mahabharata mentions the name of Indraprastha (Indarpat) as a capital of the Pandavas. Besides the antiquities collected from excavation, the important objects found from Delhi and NCR (National Capital Region) are also put up on display in this Museum.

Purana Qila Museum

The fort is one of the most enchanting tourist sites that recount the history of Delhi in detail. It is said to protect the relics of the city of Indraprastha built by the Pandavas about 5,000 years ago. Constructed by the Mughal emperor, Humayun it is a manifestation of the grandeur of the Mughal art. Humayun Darwaza, Bara Darwaza, and Talaqi Darwaza are the three majestic gates built with red sandstone. Entry was restricted through the Talaqi Darwaza as the name Talaqi means ‚Äòforbidden'. The other two attractions at the fort site are Qila-I-Kuhna Mosque and Sher Mandal. Moreover, Qila-i-Kuhna is a domed mosque with pointed arches and five doorways. With the combination of white marble and red sandstone, the mosque looks amazing. Sher Mandal is a double storey tower and it is said that Humayun died after he fell from the second floor of this tower. Also, there is a museum inside the Purana Qila complex that conserves and exhibits the various artifacts dated back to 1400 A.D. In the past, the fort has served as the place for several plays and cultural events like music and dance shows. One can enjoy a boat ride in the Purana Qila Lake, especially during day-time in winters. In the evening, a light and sound show is held that highlights the various stories connected with Delhi‚Äôs past and fort‚Äôs history.

The museum of Purana Qila is the first thing you see upon entering the fort. Inside this museum, you get to see many types of old objects that are related to the kings and the fort.
(Brief History of Museum )
Archaeological Museum, Purana Qila was established in 1973, the main purpose of which was to display the archaeological remains obtained from the archaeological excavations conducted from 1969 to 1973 on the Purana Qila mound. This excavation was done with the aim of knowing the ancient history of the fort and the archaeological remains here. This museum is located on the right side of the main entrance (Western Gate) of Purana Qila. On the basis of the archaeological remains obtained from the excavations, there is evidence of continuous settlement from this site from the Mauryan period to the early Mughal period (3rd century BC to 16th century AD). It is estimated that there must have been an ancient culture here around 1000 BC, in which painted grey pottery must have been used, since such pottery has been obtained from unlevel deposits here. This site is also known as Indraprastha Sthal.  It is mentioned in the Mahabharata epic as Indraprastha, the capital of the Pandavas. Apart from the archaeological remains obtained from excavations, important objects obtained from Delhi and the National Capital Region have also been displayed in this museum.

Feroz Shah Kotla Fort, located near Rajghat and Delhi Gate Metro Station, is an ancient structure with historical significance, but it may not be a must-visit destination for everyone. The fort is largely in ruins, with remnants of its past grandeur still visible. While the palace itself has deteriorated over time, the karagar jail remains relatively intact, showcasing its stronger construction.

Things to consider before visiting
- Not ideal in summer The fort is not recommended during peak summer due to the intense heat, as there is limited shade apart from a few large trees.
- Green spaces The big trees in the area provide a cooler breeze, making it a decent spot to relax.
- Closed well There is a well within the premises, but it is closed off to visitors.
- Casual hangout spot Instead of treating it as a must-visit historical site, it can be enjoyed as a park-like space where you can sit under the trees and have discussions with friends.
- Nearby attractions The fort is close to Arun Jaitley Stadium, making it accessible for those exploring the area.

While the fort may not be a top tourist attraction, it offers a peaceful environment for those looking to unwind amidst history. If you're in the area, it can be a good spot for a casual visit, but not a mandatory stop on a Delhi itinerary.

reviews.reviewText:
Indian Institute of Technology Delhi is one of the 23 IITs created to be Centres of Excellence for training, research and development in science, engineering and technology in India.

Established as College of Engineering in 1961, the Institute was later declared as an Institution of National Importance.
It was then accorded the status of a Deemed University with powers to decide its own academic policy, to conduct its own examinations, and to award its own degrees.

Loved the campus of IIT Delhi üíú

The Indian Institute of Technology Delhi (IIT Delhi) is one of the premier engineering institutions in India. Established in 1961, it has consistently been ranked among the top engineering colleges in the country and is known for its high academic standards, cutting-edge research, and strong industry connections.

- Located in Hauz Khas, South Delhi, the campus spans over 320 acres and includes state-of-the-art facilities, hostels, and recreational areas.
- IIT Delhi offers undergraduate, postgraduate, and doctoral programs in various fields of engineering, technology, and sciences. It also has interdisciplinary programs and management studies.
- The institute is renowned for its research output and has numerous research centers and labs. It collaborates with industries and other academic institutions globally.

- The institute encourages innovation and entrepreneurship through its various incubation centers and initiatives like the Foundation for Innovation and Technology Transfer (FITT).

Getting admission here is a dream for millions in India, but only a select few achieve it. I envy those top achievers who make it. I finally visited IIT Delhi for some technical training sponsored by my work organization. The professors are highly knowledgeable and teach exceptionally well.

Visitor parking is available only in the designated Visitor Parking area, which is about 1 km away from the LHC or seminar halls. The entry process is well managed, and the campus is very clean.

IIT Delhi is truly an iconic institution with a beautiful, sprawling campus. I recently visited and was impressed by how green, well-maintained, and peaceful the entire area is. The academic buildings are modern, and the atmosphere is filled with energy and intellect.

Entrance & Timings:
For visitors, the main entry is usually through the IIT Gate on Hauz Khas side. Security is strict, so carry a valid ID. Entry is allowed mainly during working hours (9 AM to 5 PM), and you may need a prior appointment or purpose of visit‚Äîespecially on weekdays. Visitors to hostels or specific departments should coordinate with students or faculty beforehand.

Campus Vibe:
Lots of students cycling or walking around, and you‚Äôll find cafes, libraries, hostels, and research centers spread across the campus. It's well-organized and clean. The atmosphere feels very academic and inspiring.

Nearby Access:
The campus is well-connected with the IIT Delhi metro station just outside the main gate. Auto and rickshaw availability is good too.

Tip for First-Time Visitors:
If you‚Äôre visiting for admission, exams, events, or just exploring, check your gate entry permissions in advance. Carry a government ID and check the department location online beforehand‚Äîit saves a lot of time.

Overall, IIT Delhi offers an elite experience even just as a visitor. You can truly feel the legacy and brilliance of the place the moment you step in.

IIT Delhi is truly an exceptional institution that has left an indelible mark on my academic and professional journey. The faculty's expertise and passion for teaching are unparalleled, and the infrastructure is state-of-the-art. The rigorous academic environment fosters innovation, creativity, and growth, pushing students to excel in their chosen fields.

I'm grateful for the experience and opportunities IIT Delhi provided.

If you're considering IIT Delhi, I highly recommend it. The institute's commitment to academic excellence, research, and innovation makes it an ideal platform for students to pursue their passions and achieve their goals. With its rich history, esteemed faculty, and talented student body, IIT Delhi is a hub for learning, growth, and success.

One of the top engineering institutes in India!
IIT Delhi has an excellent academic atmosphere with world-class faculty, state-of-the-art labs, and a vibrant campus life. The infrastructure is modern, and the research facilities are outstanding. Students here are bright, competitive, and collaborative. The campus is green, well-maintained, and filled with innovation. Great place for technical education and personal growth!

IIT Delhi is not just an institute ‚Äî it‚Äôs a symbol of excellence, innovation, and ambition. The campus is vibrant and full of energy, with brilliant minds pushing boundaries in every field. A place where ideas come to life and futures are shaped.

placeMetadata.name: Imam Zamin's Tomb

sources.snippet: Located near the Alai Darwaza, in the Qutub Complex, is the tomb of Imam Zamin, a well-known Turkestani Imam. Imam Zamin was the Imam of the Quwwat-u-islam Mosque. He came to Delhi in the 15 th century and lived in the Qutub Complex premises during the rule of Sikandar Lodi.
sources.shortName: 17 Historical Monuments in Delhi | Monuments in Delhi

placeMetadata.description: Large sandstone monument containing the tomb of the namesake 16th-century Muslim figure.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled within the historic Qutub Minar Complex in Delhi, Imam Zamin's Tomb stands as a striking sandstone monument that pays homage to a revered 16th-century Muslim figure. This charming mausoleum, with its octagonal base and intricate latticework, is not just an architectural delight but also holds significant historical value.
placeMetadata.address: Qutub Minar Complex Rd, Seth Sarai, Mehrauli, New Delhi, Delhi 110030, India

reviews.reviewText: This small mausoleum in the proverbial shadows of the Qutab Minar I found to be probably the most beautiful and photogenic place in the entire complex. The tomb itself is rather small and relatively simple, but it is in good condition and looks great. But when viewed with the Qutab Minar in the background, it becomes stunning. Absolutely would recommend visiting this place.
Beautifully decorated but not very big, not very impressive. You can't go inside. Pretty well preserved. Take 2-3 pictures and move on.

The tomb of Imam Zamin is a historical monument located in the Qutub Minar Complex Road in the Seth Sarai area of Mehrauli in New Delhi, India. The tomb is named after Imam Zamin, who was a holy man and a Sufi saint who lived during the 16th century AD.

Imam Zamin was a renowned Islamic scholar and a spiritual leader who was known for his piety and wisdom. He was born in Turkestan and later moved to India, where he spent the rest of his life spreading the teachings of Islam and Sufism. Imam Zamin was also a patron of the arts and was known for his love of calligraphy and poetry.

The tomb of Imam Zamin was built in 1538 AD during the reign of the Mughal Emperor Humayun. The tomb is a small, square-shaped building that is made of red sandstone and is decorated with intricate carvings and inscriptions. The tomb is topped with a dome that is supported by four pillars.

The tomb is located in the Qutub Minar Complex, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the most important historical sites in Delhi. The complex is home to several other monuments, including the famous Qutub Minar, which is a towering minaret that was built in the 12th century AD.

The tomb of Imam Zamin is a beautiful example of Mughal architecture and is known for its intricate carvings and delicate designs. The tomb is also famous for its calligraphy, which is considered to be some of the finest in the world.

Today, the tomb of Imam Zamin is a popular tourist attraction in Delhi and is visited by thousands of people every year. The tomb is a reminder of the rich cultural heritage of India and the enduring legacy of the Sufi saints who played an important role in shaping the country's history and culture.

The beautiful square-shaped tomb on an elevated platform, built mainly of sandstone, with an octagonal base, is located near the Alai Darwaza in Qutub Minar Complex, Delhi.

The tomb belongs to Imam Zamin, it is believed that he came to India in around 1500 AD from Turkestan and became the Imam in Quwwat-ul-Islam mosque.

According to the inscription on the entrance of his tomb, the mausoleum was built by Zamin himself between 1537 and 1538 during the reign of Humayun. He died in 1539 and was buried at the center of the mausoleum.

Tomb of Imam Zamin

Background

Imam Zamin was a direct descendant of¬†Muhammad ¬†and his original name was Muhammad Ali. Zamin was thus a¬†Sayyid and belonged to the¬†Chishti sect¬†of Sufism. It is believed that he migrated from¬†Turkestan to Delhi during the reign of Sultan¬†Sikandar Lodi, and subsequently became the¬†Imam(chief priest) of the Quwwat-ul-Islam mosque, at the¬†Qutb Minar complex.

According to the inscription on the entrance, the mausoleum was built by Zamin between 1537 and 1538 during the reign of¬†Humayun. He died in 1539.Located east of the¬†Alai Darwaza, the tomb was constructed long after the original group of monuments and was the last addition to the Qutb Minar complex. Zamin is buried at the centre of the mausoleum.

Architecture

The tomb is built in the Lodhi architectural style.¬†The mausoleum is square in shape and measures 7.3 metres (24¬†ft) in both length and breadth.¬†The roof is supported by twelve pillars and is surmounted by a sandstone dome with¬†jalis ¬†on all the sides, except the west and south.¬†The dome rises from an octagonal drum and is decorated with a marble panel above the¬†chhajja(overhanging eaves or cover of a roof) along with a double row of¬†crenelles. Marble is extensively used for the interior ornamentation and in the construction of the¬†cenotaph. The western side of the mausoleum contains a marble-wrought¬†Mihrab ¬†(niche in the wall of a mosque that indicates the direction towards which the Muslims pray).¬†The entrance, located at the southern side, is also made of marble.

The entire sandstone structure was originally covered by polished¬†stucco, a portion of which is still extant. The name of Zamin is written in the¬†Naskh¬†script over the doorway of the entrance.

placeMetadata.name: Mumtaz Mahal

sources.snippet: Mumtaz Mahal, also known as Burhanpur ki Mumtaz, is a lesser-known historical gem in Delhi. Situated near Humayun's Tomb, this 17th-century structure stands as a testament to Mughal architectural elegance. Despite being overshadowed by its grander counterparts, Mumtaz Mahal offers a tranquil escape and a glimpse into Delhi's rich historical legacy.
sources.shortName: 30 Historical Places In Delhi For A Heritage Tour 2024

placeMetadata.description: Ornate marble palace building at the Red Fort, home to the complex's archaeological museum.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled within the iconic Red Fort, Mumtaz Mahal is a hidden treasure that often goes unnoticed amidst Delhi's more famous landmarks. This exquisite 17th-century palace, also known as Burhanpur ki Mumtaz, showcases the stunning Mughal architectural style and offers visitors a serene retreat from the bustling city. Overlooking the Yamuna River, it forms part of a complex of six palaces interconnected by the enchanting Nahr-i-Bishisht or 'Stream of Paradise.'
placeMetadata.address: M63V+R93, Red Fort, Old Delhi, New Delhi, Delhi 110006, India

reviews.reviewText:
If you want to see the entire Red Fort in one go, please go before 5:00 PM because after that they ban entry at some places, due to the sound and light show. and only those people who have booked tickets for the show can stay after 5:00 PM.
*There are 2 sound and light shows everyday. The first one is from 6:30 pm to 7:30 pm and the second one is from 7:45 pm to 8:45 pm.
The first 5 minutes of the show takes place in the open so that the rest of the public can also watch the show and gain knowledge along with enjoyment.
Earlier, entry to the Red Fort was free and there was no show of any kind. But recently, an Indian conglomerate group named Dalmia Bharat has started presenting this sound and light show, also called *Jai Hind* in short, and the money earned through tickets is used in the maintenance of the Red Fort.

The Mumtaz Mahal is located in the Red Fort, Delhi. The Mumtaz Mahal is one of the six main palaces that were positioned facing the Yamuna River. All six palaces were connected by the Stream of Paradise, a raceway which ran through them.

placeMetadata.name: Zafar Mahal

sources.snippet: The final monument built in the time of the Mughals is the Zafar Mahal. It is located in the middle of Mehrauli and is located near the western entrance of the dargah in Khawaja Bakhtiyar Kaki, this Mahal was named by the Emperor Akbar II in honor of the son of his Bahadur Shah Zafar. A large portion of this summer palace is currently in disrepair.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Zafar Mahal is a historical landmark in Delhi, India that was built by the Mughal Emperor, Akbar and later used by his son, Bahadur Shah Zafar. It is now ruined but still attracts tourists due to its unique architecture and history.
placeMetadata.address: Mehrauli Village, Mehrauli, New Delhi, Delhi 110030, India

reviews.reviewText:
Zafar Mahal is last monumental structure built as a summer palace during the fading years of the Mughal era. The building has two parts-The palace which was built first by Akbar Shah II in the 18th century, and the entrance gate called Hathi gate that was reconstructed in the 19th century by Bahadur Shah Zafar II. Bahadur Shah Zafar wished to be buried in the precincts of the Zafar Mahal but was deported by the British to Rangoon, after the First War of Indian Independence in 1857, where he died of old age.

A masjid called the Moti Masjid built by Bahadur Shah I was a private mosque of the royal family, which has now become part of the palace compound. The mosque is a small and unique three-domed structure made of white marble. The austere mosque has the mihrab on the west direction of prayer but is unusually not embellished, except for little border of floral carving on the south at the top edge of a dado

Hathi gate is so called because a full decorated elephant with the howdah could pass through it. An inscription on the main arch credits building of the gate by Bahadur Shah II in the eleventh year of his accession as Emperor in 1847-48 AD. A broad Chhajja built in the Mughal style is a striking feature of the arch. At the entrance gate, there are small projecting windows flanked by curved and covered Bengali domes. On both sides of the arch, two ornate medallions in the form of large lotuses have been provided. The gateway also depicts a classic tripolia or three-arch opening.

Zafar Mahal is the most significant late Mughal monument in India.
The Palace is located in Mehrauli village in South Delhi. It was erected by Akbar Shah II in the early 19th century and then renovated in 1847‚Äì48 by Bahadur Shah Zafar II.
The last Mughal Emperor, was a mystic, an accomplished poet and a skilled calligrapher of Mughals era.
The Zafar Mahal served as a summer palace for the royals and also served as a resting place for the royals during their visit to the dargah.
The grand entrance of the palace is known as Hathi Gate and is designed as to pass  through elephants with the king's seat.
A beautiful mosque Moti Masjid is next to Zafar Mahal.
Zafar Mahal, an Archaeological Survey of India (ASI)-protected monument.
During my visit, the palace was under the process of restoration.
Must visit with Qutub Minar trip !!!

While the palace is named after Bahadur shah Zafar ii, he only built the gate you enter by. The actual palace was built by his ancestor Akbar Shah ii. Most of it is in ruins. But the moti masjid is still intact. There are also ruins of four Mughal emperors but not Bahadur shah who died in Rangoon. The tombs are quite beautiful and carved with urdu calligraphy.

Visited Zafar Mahal, The resting place od Last Mughal Emperor Bahadur Shah Zafar. Sadly, the experience was disappointing. The place, full of history, is not cared for.
Built in the early 19th century, considered the last monumental structure of the Mughal era.
This Resting Palace Served as a summer palace, particularly during the "Phoolwaalon ki sair" festival celebrating Sufi saint Hazrat Qutubuddin Bakhtiyar Kaki (whose tomb is also next to this Palace) and this palace witness to the waning years of the Mughal dynasty, mirroring the empire's declining financial resources in its simpler construction compared to other grand Mughal palaces.

Upon arrival i noticed, There's only one guard around, who seemed to be there merely for formality. The lack of care and proper security results in the almost vandalised condition of the site. It's was disheartening to see such a significant historic monument being neglected in this manner.

Furthermore, instead of visitors paying their respects, I observed a group of elderly people playing cards near the premises. This disrespect towards the monument is a reflection of the lack of maintenance and oversight.

Bahadur Shah Zafar's empty grave at Zafar Mahal tells a poignant tale of his fate and the decline of the Mughal Empire. It's a powerful reminder of history's twists and turns, left unnoticed amidst the neglect. As Zafar himself wrote,

This poetic line hints at the tragic irony of his burial, adding depth to the site's significance.
Nearby, Moti Masjid, a beautiful mosque, suffers the same fate. It's a shame for such significant places to be forgotten.

Moti Masjid, located next to Zafar Mahal, is a replica of the one in Agra's Red Fort. It's a gem of architecture, and it aslo suffers the same fate
The grand entrance is named as Hathi Gate for its wide design allowing an elephant with a seat (houdah) to pass through.

I hoped the Archaeological Survey of India would do better. They must act to protect and restore Zafar Mahal, the grave, and Moti Masjid. These places deserve respect and care.

Despite its importance, the neglect makes visiting Zafar Mahal less enjoyable. I hope it gets the care it deserves soon.

Entry Fees:

Zafar Mahal is the last seat of the Mughal Empire. Although the Mahal was not built by Bahadur Shah Zafar by his earlier rulers. He had only built the Gate 'Hathi Darwaza' big enough for an elephant's entry. The palace is in ruins now. Its walls are crumbling, and it badly needs a restoration or preservation, but I fear that would happen in the near future, and this palace of historical importance would soon be in ruins. It's close to the Dargah Hazrat Qutbuddin Bakhtiyar Kaki.

This used to be a summer palace that was built by the second last Mughal Emperor Akbar II in the 19th century. The main gate (known as Hathi Gate) however, is a later addition by his son, the last Emperor Bahadur Shah II (Zafar), by whose name the palace eventually came to be known.

Inside are ruins of whatever is left of the palace as most of it is now encroached; a couple of graves spread across towards the left side; Moti Masjid, a Mosque that was commissioned in the early 18th century by Aurangzeb Alamgir's son, the 7th Mughal Emperor Bahadur Shah I aka Shah Alam I for private use of the royal family; adjacent to which is a marble enclosure within which are 4 graves and space for a 5th. 3 of these graves are of Emperors, namely Bahadur Shah I (who had Moti Masjid commissioned), Shah Alam II, and Akbar II (who commissioned the palace). 1 grave that is a bit distant from all, towards the corner, is said to be of Mirza Fath-ul-Mulk Bahadur, the last Crown Prince of the Mughal Empire. There is also a noticeable empty plot of land. This is where the last Mughal Emperor Bahadur Shah Zafar wished to be buried but this wish was not fulfilled as he was exiled to Burma where he died and was buried with great secrecy.

Definitely a great place to visit if you want to see and experience some of the last few mughal constructions ever commissioned up-close. Barely any people visit, those who do are mostly students or guided tours, and even those are rare. There's a security guard who can usually be found inside.

Incorporating some Delhi Sultanate era buildings, Zafar Mahal was built by Mughal Emperor Akbar Shah II in the early part of the nineteenth century.
His son the last of the Mughals, Emperor Bahadur Shah Zafar added the imposing red sandstone gateway which is almost three storeys high probably being the last gateway built by a Mughal in India.
This monument is protected by Archaeological Survey of India but there is no need to buy tickets as of now but there is a guard to provide security both for the monument and for visitors.
It's located almost at the back side of the Sufi shrine of Hazrat Qutubuddin Bakhtiyar Kaki which is much easier to locate on Google Maps and once here just ask any shopkeeper for directions and you'll reach this beautiful monument for sure.
Not meant for persons with reduced mobility as one has to climb a number of stairs and cobbled stones.

It's a nice place but very filthy, dirty. It's too old, give nostalgic feeling. It would hv been amazing if people around , land mafia won't have constructed houses next to it. Time has hit this structure too hard, parts of it have already degraded to dust. Some roofs are gone. Some parts are deliberately standing or have been renovated. Don't come alone,. Gives haunted feeling due to no crowd, not even a dog. Yes gaurd is present.

placeMetadata.name: British Council

sources.shortName: New Delhi Architecture: Buildings India

placeMetadata.address: 17, KG Marg, Atul Grove Road, Janpath, Connaught Place, New Delhi, Delhi 110001, India

reviews.reviewText:
British Council is UK‚Äôs Organisation for cultural relations and educational opportunities.
It is the official headquarters of British High Commission.
I was completely overwhelmed and amazed by the beauty of the Building. I immediately fell in love with the place and the vibe it resonates. I found the place meticulously handled and maintained. They have a good system for taking and addressing the enquiries.
They have a Library with array of Books and Novels in English Language. I loved the space it provided and the crowd that it attracts. You have to have the membership of the British Council Library to have access to it and to have space to read and or study. Not only this, if you have the membership, you get the whole wide space to have your study or even work with your laptops i.e. you are not restricted just to the library to read/study or work. I loved this arrangement and eagerly want to start the membership.
British Council provides many courses in English Language including CELTA, Business English etc.

Must visit and have a beautiful experience:)

#Nearby Barakhamba Metro Station Gate-6 #Opposite to Parikarma The Revolving Restaurant# Nearby Subway to cross the road# Secured# Neat & Clean# Quick bite Cafe inside# Vehicle Parking not available# Library inside for registered customers# Elevator inside# Value for money# Good curriculum and instructors to teach English# Wheel chaired accessible# X-ray scanning of each.

One can feel the difference from the point one approaches the main entrance of British Council. Staffs are agile but courteous.

This is one of the best places to learn English language & Business Communication Skills.

Kids (5+) and Adults can enroll English language classes. They also arrange summer classes for Kids which is one of the "must do" thing.

Library has huge collection related to literature and other topics. It also provide sitting area for study for members. Kids section is separate and has ample and varied collection to keep them.busy with.

Ambience is good. It uses state-of-the-art-technology where ever possible.

Canteen is there on the ground floor which serves tasty foods. Price is on slightly higher side.

My brother and I visited the British Council Division, KG Marg, New Delhi with a lot of excitement to enroll in the English speaking course and take library membership. On our first visit (2nd August), we were assisted by a very kind and professional lady who explained everything in great detail and made us feel truly welcomed. We left fully convinced to join.

However, when we visited again the next day (3rd August) to complete the admission and clarify a few more queries, our experience was completely opposite. The person sitting at the front desk behaved very rudely and was extremely unprofessional. He didn‚Äôt respond to our questions politely and dismissed everything we had been told earlier, without any patience or courtesy.

We were very disappointed. We have always respected the British Council as a reputed institution, but this kind of behavior‚Äîespecially from someone representing the organization at the reception‚Äîis not acceptable. It left us feeling unwelcome and unsure about joining.

This feedback comes from a place of genuine disappointment, not anger. I hope the British Council takes this seriously and ensures a more respectful environment for visitors.

Not recommended this institute because in this, no teacher teaches about English and no one teaches how we can form the sentence while talking.
They only focus on debate on different topics and pronunciation only. If there is a error in your sentence, no mentor tells your mistake.
Even few teachers are not capable to manage the debate sessions.
I think because of all these issues, they are not giving a single demo class to students and charged so much for 60 classes that is 38,000 to 40,000.

So, the British Council in Delhi is pretty awesome when it comes to IELTS classes. They have a fantastic teaching faculty who are experienced and knowledgeable. They really know their stuff! And the best part is, their classes are cost-effective too. So you get quality teaching without breaking the bank. It's a win-win! üòÑüëç

It‚Äôs a nice building in Kasturba Gandhi marg, Connaught Place. You can go as a visitor during the day and check out their library or sit in their spacious cafe on the ground floor called the Tin whistle.
We went to check out their library and some other courses for self and children. Master certification courses for English post which you can teach and prepare students for IELTS.

The menu is not much . Simple limited items like tea, coffee, sandwiches, burger, a bit of bakery items, croissant etc. it‚Äôs spacious though. Quiet place. Neat and clean. Masala tea is for 95 Rs. It was average. High priced as compared.
Library is on the 1st floor. Other inquiries can be made from the staff seated there .

The worst decision of 2023 was for me to renew my membership of thr British Council Library, after a gap of a few years. Thought I was becoming a member of a library but to my woe found out that this is now more of the ubiquitous "coaching centres" than an actual library.
More than half of the book shelves have been shelved in favour of seating for those who need "coaching". Almost all of them are rote learning the management books and books required for IELTS. The entire fabulous DVD and media section has disappeared too.
What astounds me most is the concept of an educational institution like the British Council lying/misrepresenting facts. While it clearly states on the British Council website that upon becoming a member, one can access DVD's, the entire section has been removed.
Such is the lack of decorum at the British Council library/coaching centre, that the so called students hog all the seats while browsing content on their smartphones and extend their legs and belongings in such a manner that I was unable to browse the books on the shelves. No manners!

ops.insert: Landmark 17th-century Mughal fortress built in towering red sandstone, now a complex of museums.
17th-century, red sandstone Mughal-style mosque with a 25,000 capacity & 40m high minarets.
The tomb of Safdarjung, the viceroy of Awadh, with a palm-lined garden, a library and pavilions.
Opulent red-sandstone tomb of Mughal Emperor Humayun, built in 1572 & surrounded by formal gardens.
Religious site also known as the Bah√°‚Äô√≠ House of Worship, opened in 1986 to those of all religions.
13 architectural astronomy instruments built in 1724 at the orders of Mughal emperor Muhammad Shah.
5-story facility with a Tibetan art museum & library, plus lectures & events about Buddhist culture.

ops.insert: Home to a repertory theatre company, this venue also hosts dance & music performances.
Imposing triumphal arch commemorating the Indian soldiers killed in the First World War.
A British-era public park featuring ancient tombs, rose & herb gardens, bonsai trees and a lake.
Official residence plus Mughal and herbal gardens of the President of India, with visits by request.
Step-well from the 10th century with ornate stone details, including soaring arched walls & alcoves.
200-acre archeological site with some 100 historic monuments, including tombs & Delhi's oldest fort.
This octagonal tomb known for its sunken garden was built for a noble in the Humayun's Tomb complex.
Built of red sandstone in 1650, this elegant, subtly domed mosque is the site of Eid celebrations.

Delhi, India‚Äôs capital territory, is a massive metropolitan area in the country‚Äôs north. In Old Delhi, a neighborhood dating to the 1600s, stands the imposing Mughal-era Red Fort, a symbol of India, and the sprawling Jama Masjid mosque, whose courtyard accommodates 25,000 people. Nearby is Chandni Chowk, a vibrant bazaar filled with food carts, sweets shops and spice stalls.
Landmark red sandstone & white marble mosque with 3 domes & 131-ft minarets built in 1656.
Archway in city walls, dating from the 16th century & scene of murders in 1857‚Äôs Great Rebellion.
73m tapering tower built in 1193 by Qutab-ud-din Aibak after defeat of Delhi's last Hindu kingdom.
Domed Sufi Muslim shrine dedicated to Hazrat Nizamuddin, offering daily prayers & vegetarian food.
Home to many Tibetan refugees, this area features a Buddhist temple & Tibetan restaurants.
Remains of a 14th-century Tughlaq period stone fort with ramparts & battlements intact.
Monumental, 16th-century mosque & tomb complex within Mehrauli Archaeological Park.
Sandstone remains of a fortress thought to be haunted, surrounded by gardens & cricket grounds.
Ornate marble palace building at the Red Fort, home to the complex's archaeological museum.
Large sandstone monument containing the tomb of the namesake 16th-century Muslim figure.

ops.insert: Over 11,000 artisans worked on this lavishly decorated Hindu temple complex inaugurated in 2005.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
New Delhi is a city where history and modernity coexist in a stunning architectural tapestry. From the majestic Red Fort, a symbol of Mughal power, to the serene Lotus Temple, which welcomes all faiths, the city is a treasure trove of diverse structures that tell the story of its rich past. Each monument, whether it‚Äôs the intricate carvings of the Qutub Minar or the grandeur of Humayun‚Äôs Tomb, offers a unique glimpse into the artistic and cultural evolution of India. As you wander through the bustling streets, you‚Äôll find that every corner holds a piece of history waiting to be explored.

At Wanderlog, we‚Äôre passionate about uncovering the stories behind these remarkable buildings. Whether you‚Äôre marveling at the intricate designs of Jama Masjid or strolling through the lush gardens of Lodhi Garden, New Delhi‚Äôs architecture invites you to pause and reflect. This city is not just about the sights; it‚Äôs about the experiences that come with them. So grab your camera and get ready to explore the architectural wonders that make New Delhi a must-visit destination for history buffs and casual travelers alike.

data.title: The 40 best photo spots in New Delhi

placeMetadata.name: India Gate

sources.snippet: Looking a little like the famous Arc de Triomphe in Paris, the equally impressive India Gate is a magnificent stone arch built as a memorial to Indian soldiers killed in WWI. An eternal flame burns beneath the massive structure, and its walls are inscribed with the names of more than 90,000 soldiers who died in the conflict. Standing on a base of red stone and featuring a shallow domed bowl on top that is occasionally filled with burning oil (usually only on important anniversaries), the structure dominates the parkland around it, an always busy area with crowds of tourists and locals alike enjoying a picnic or simply relaxing.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Delhi & New Delhi

sources.snippet: Constructed in 1921 in order to pay tribute to around 90,000 Indian Army soldiers who died in WWI, the Northwest Frontier operations and the 1919 Anglo-Afghan War, this imposing 42m high structure was modelled on Paris‚Äô Arc de Triomphe. There is a constant buzz in the park and pools surrounding the gate as families picnic on the grass and swim in the water. Vendors selling street food,  budhdhi ke bal (candyfloss or ‚Äòold lady‚Äôs hair‚Äô) and toys mill around beneath the arch and on the long road that leads from the presidential palace towards the arch.
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable & Photogenic Spots in Delhi, India

sources.snippet: This towering war memorial archway pays tribute to the 70-thousand Indian soldiers who died in World War I fighting for the British army, and is a standard stop on every Delhi sightseeing tour. Originally called the All India War Memorial, it soars 40 metres high and is particularly striking at sunset when the light casts a soft glow over it. Looking for a place to stay in Delhi?
sources.shortName: Best places to visit in Delhi for photography

sources.snippet: The India Gate, built in 1931 and modeled off the Arc de Triomphe in Paris is a sight to see in itself, but the real attraction here is the  chaos and crowds of the surrounding park. From street vendors to school children, tourists, and performers, the park here is somewhere between a party and Times Square - and we just got a pack of bubbles and enjoyed the chaos.
sources.shortName: The Delhi Photo Guide: Top 16 Most Instagrammable Places in New and Old Delhi, India

sources.snippet: This is one of the most pristine spots in the city with the view of Rashtrapati Bhavan on one side and India Gate on the other. Sunsets are magical when the skies are pale yellow matching the straight yellow line running across the road. Night time means blue sky and pink building as the structures illuminate everything around with vibrant lights covering them.
sources.shortName: It's Time To Get Camera Ready For The 10 Most Instagrammable Spots In Delhi

sources.snippet: The 42 meter high India Gate stands at the center of New Delhi providing its famous ‚ÄúArc-de-Triomphe‚Äù like archway synonymous with city. It was built as a war memorial to the 82,000 soldiers of the Indian Army who died in the period 1914‚Äì21 in the First World War. Today, it also serves as Delhi‚Äôs most popular selfie spot and tourist attraction.
sources.shortName: City Street Guides by f.d. walker: A Street Photography Guide to Delhi, India

sources.snippet: India Gate has in many ways proven to be the unofficial symbol of Delhi and after all, why shouldn't it be?. This iconic war memorial is a hotspot for all generations and is an extremely picturesque spot as well. Head over here with your cams and besties and click some stunning photos with this even more stunning beauty in the background.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Places For An Evening Photoshoot In Delhi

sources.snippet: One of the must-visit tourist attractions in Delhi, India Gate is one place you can‚Äôt afford to miss. Originally referred to as the All-India War Memorial, it has the names of Indian soldiers who sacrificed their lives in World War I, engraved on its wall. The names of martyrs of Anglo-Afghan War are also engraved on its wall.
sources.shortName: Delhi Darshan Tour - Best Day Sightseeing Places

sources.snippet: Nobody can neglect the essence and significance of India Gate in every Indian‚Äôs life. Imposing affluent innovation, it becomes a symbol of nationality and pride monument of India's freedom fighters. Besides, couples find India Gate the perfect location to enjoy their bonding and emotions.
sources.shortName: Top 20 Paid & Free Locations in Delhi for a Perfect Pre-Wedding Shoot

sources.snippet: A post shared by Anupam Thakur (@at__321) on Mar 17, 2020 at 8:25pm PDT. The structure designed by British architect Edwin Lutyens commemorates the soldiers who lost their lives in the First World War. The gorgeous landmark makes for a perfect frame no matter at what time you visit it.
sources.shortName: Best Photography Spots Of Delhi You Must Explore Post Lockdown

sources.snippet: It is not something new to explain that India Gate is an important photographic site of the city. The monument is best visited at night for a sepia mode picture, with the lights lit. However, If you visit during daytime, you can get good pictures of garden, lake, boating and others.
sources.shortName: Best Place For Photoshoot in Delhi

sources.snippet: It is not something new to explain that India Gateis an important photographic site of the city. The monument is best visited at night for a sepia mode picture, with the lights lit. If you visit during daytime, you can get good pictures of garden, lake, boating and others.
sources.shortName: Ten Top Photographic Spots in Delhi -

sources.snippet: The India Gate is one of my favourite attractions in the whole of Delhi!. It‚Äôs an arched memorial nearby Rajpath and was built to commemorate 6,000 Indian soldiers who died fighting in the First World War. The foundation stone was laid down in 1921.

placeMetadata.description: Imposing triumphal arch commemorating the Indian soldiers killed in the First World War.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: India Gate, located at the eastern end of Raj Path in New Delhi, is a grand triumphal arch that serves as a war memorial for Indian soldiers who lost their lives in World War I. Designed by renowned architect Edward Lutyens and inaugurated in 1921, it commemorates over 70,000 Indian soldiers who perished during the war. The monument also honors more than 13,500 British and Indian soldiers killed in the Afghan war of 1919.
placeMetadata.address: Kartavya Path, India Gate, New Delhi, Delhi 110001, India

reviews.reviewText:
India Gate remains one of the most iconic and well-maintained landmarks in Delhi. Visited over the weekend, and despite it being a popular spot, there was absolutely no wait time, which made the experience even better.

The surroundings were clean, the lawns were well-kept, and the atmosphere felt peaceful, especially around sunset. Perfect for photography lovers ‚Äî the lighting and backdrop make for stunning pictures.
Security was visible but not intrusive, and crowd management was smooth. It's a great place to take a stroll, enjoy some quiet time, or just soak in the historic significance of the monument.

Highly recommended for both tourists and locals who want to experience a piece of India‚Äôs heritage in a calm, scenic setting!

India Gate Morning Visit Review üáÆüá≥‚ú®

Visiting India Gate in the morning is a truly serene and patriotic experience. Here‚Äôs a detailed review of my experience:

Perfect Morning Vibes üåÖ:
Early morning around 6-8 AM is the best time to visit. The rising sun adds a golden glow to the structure, making the view magical and peaceful.

Peaceful Atmosphere üïäÔ∏è:
Compared to the busy hours, the morning is calm, with fewer crowds. It allows you to enjoy the architecture and surroundings in peace.

Cleanliness & Maintenance üßπüåø:
The area is very neat and clean, with well-maintained gardens and tidy paths. Kudos to the authorities for keeping such a historic site spotless.

Ideal for Morning Walks & Jogging üëü:
Many locals come for jogging or yoga. The cool breeze and open space make it a refreshing start to the day.

Patriotic Feelings Evoked üáÆüá≥‚ù§Ô∏è:
Standing before the eternal flame and reading the names engraved on the monument fills your heart with pride and gratitude.

Perfect for Photography üì∏:
The soft light during the morning enhances the beauty of the monument and is ideal for taking stunning pictures.

Accessibility & Safety üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è:
Easily accessible and well-guarded by security. You feel completely safe while enjoying your visit.

In short, if you want a peaceful, clean, and meaningful experience at India Gate, plan your visit in the early morning hours. It will leave you refreshed, proud, and connected to the soul of India.

placeMetadata.name: Humayun‚Äôs Tomb

sources.snippet: The tomb of Mughal Emperor Humayun is a real architectural wonder and one of the most impressive buildings in the whole of Delhi. Predating the Taj Mahal by around 60 years, it is thought to have inspired India‚Äôs most famous structure, although, rather than being built entirely from in white, the marble is reserved for the enormous dome and the inlays of the red sandstone arches, all of which follow the strict rules of Islamic geometry. The complex and its perfectly manicured gardens contain a number of other monuments and tombs, but none are quite as impressive or Instagram-worth as the tomb of Humayun.
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable & Photogenic Spots in Delhi, India

sources.snippet: Set in a lovely, large square garden, Humayun's Tomb is a lofty mausoleum constructed of white marble and red sandstone. It was designed as a prototype of the Taj Mahal in Agra and is an excellent example of Mughal architecture. Built in the mid-16th century by Haji Begum as a memorial to her husband by Humayun's senior widow, the tomb is surrounded by lush formal gardens and other tombs including Humayun's barber and the Tomb of Isa Khan (the architect of the Taj Mahal), a fine example of Lodi architecture and octagonal in shape.

sources.snippet: Back in 2015, the  St+art India Foundation, an organization dedicated to making art more accessible, teamed up with the Indian government to allow street artists to use the buildings in this inner-city neighbourhood as enormous canvases. As a result, what was once a rather dull stretch of government housing blocks is now home to over 50 vibrant murals created by local and foreign artists, covering themes ranging from Indian culture and celebrities to social issues. reviews.reviewText:
Visited on July 7th, 2025 ‚Äì Day 4 in India

After taking a break yesterday to explore the markets, we continued our sightseeing today with our private tour guide. Our morning began at Rajghat, and from there we made our way to Jama Masjid.

It‚Äôs one of the largest mosques in India and a true architectural marvel, built centuries ago during the Mughal era. As soon as we arrived, we were swept into the lively energy of Old Delhi‚Äîthe sounds, the colors, the movement‚Äîit‚Äôs a kind of chaos that somehow feels alive and exciting rather than overwhelming.

The climb up the steps to the mosque was a fun adventure for our daughters (5 and 7), who took it on like a challenge and loved every minute. Once we entered the vast open courtyard, everything shifted. The noise faded, and it felt incredibly peaceful and calm inside. There‚Äôs something very spiritual about standing there, surrounded by towering minarets, marble domes, and centuries of history.

Our girls were full of curiosity, asking questions about how people pray, what the call to prayer means, and why everyone was barefoot. It turned into a beautiful moment of quiet reflection and learning. We took our time to take it all in, and even in the middle of a bustling city, it felt like we were in our own quiet world.

We absolutely loved this visit‚Äîit was meaningful, memorable, and full of life. Highly recommend for anyone traveling through Delhi, especially with kids who are curious and adventurous üôèüèΩ.

These monuments are beautiful, amazingly and well built structures. The architecture is so impressive. Some of the structures are still intact. But the Place doesn't maintain properly it looks so dirty mainly in the exterior.

If you tour guide says this is biggest mosque of India, It is absolutely lies. Biggest mosque of India is in Bhopal (MP).
3 Onion Shapes domes with 2 Minars (Tower) this particular Persian design introduced by Shahjahan in 17th Century & copied by across the globe. Therefore, Jama Mosque is famous bcz of its unique architecture.
The mosque has a peaceful atmosphere despite being in the heart of busy Chandni Chowk. A must-visit for history, culture, and photography lovers!

It is a very beautiful also a very rushy mosque...
Children should be kept safely when visiting this place. It is very crowded.
The shops infront are provided different varieties of things.
The food Street which is situated at the back provides very delicious different varieties...
Time goes very speedily when we keep enjoying that big area....

I visited Jama Masjid yesterday, and while the architecture is absolutely stunning‚Äîa magnificent display of Mughal artistry with grand domes, intricate marble work, and an expansive courtyard that makes you feel the weight of history‚Äîthe experience was far from perfect. The premises and surrounding area were not well maintained, with dirty walkways, open drains emitting unpleasant smells, and a large, unmanaged crowd both inside and outside the mosque, which made moving around difficult and diminished the peacefulness such a place should offer. The nearby market, though vibrant and full of life, felt chaotic and poorly organized, adding to the sense of disorder, and I truly believe it would benefit from proper management, covered drains, and better sanitation. From what I have seen in other people‚Äôs accounts, my impressions are widely shared‚Äîmany visitors praise the sheer beauty and spiritual presence of Jama Masjid but express disappointment about the lack of cleanliness, the overwhelming number of visitors at any given time, and the constant haggling or touting near the entrances. While the breathtaking view from the minaret and the sense of stepping into a living piece of history remain unforgettable highlights, the lack of upkeep and effective crowd control significantly detract from what could otherwise be a truly majestic experience, and for that reason I would rate my visit 3 out of 5.

Jama Masjid is a stunning and peaceful mosque right in the heart of Old Delhi. The architecture is beautiful, and walking through the huge courtyard feels like stepping back in time. A must-do is climbing up the minaret (tower) ‚Äì from the top you get a breathtaking view over the city, with sights like the Red Fort clearly visible in the distance. Entry is inexpensive (400 Rupien, 200 extra for the tower), and it‚Äôs one of the absolute highlights of Delhi.

The Masjid campus inside is good. Washrooms very dirty. You can also go up one of a minar; you just have to buy a ticket  of Rs. 100. It‚Äôs very crowded outside the masjid, take care of your belongings. Opens at 11 AM.

VISITED JAMA MASJID IN DELHI, AND IT‚ÄôS TRULY A MASTERPIECE OF MUGHAL ARCHITECTURE! THE GRANDEUR OF THE MOSQUE, WITH ITS MASSIVE COURTYARD AND STUNNING RED SANDSTONE AND MARBLE WORK, IS BREATHTAKING. THE INTRICATE DETAILS AND THE SERENE ATMOSPHERE MAKE IT A MUST-VISIT. CLIMBING THE MINARET OFFERS AN INCREDIBLE VIEW OF OLD DELHI, THOUGH IT‚ÄôS A BIT OF A SQUEEZE! THE PLACE IS WELL-MAINTAINED, BUT IT CAN GET CROWDED, SO EARLY MORNINGS ARE BEST. RESPECTFUL ATTIRE IS A MUST, AND THE STAFF ARE HELPFUL IN GUIDING VISITORS. A PERFECT BLEND OF HISTORY, CULTURE, AND SPIRITUALITY.
THANK YOU . . . .

reviews.reviewText:
The Lotus Temple is one of the most peaceful and beautiful places in Delhi. The architecture is stunning‚Äîit really does look like a blooming lotus surrounded by water ponds. The best part is the calm and serene atmosphere inside the prayer hall, where people of all religions can sit quietly and meditate. The gardens around the temple are very well maintained and add to the beauty of the place.

Entry is free, but it‚Äôs best to visit early in the morning or in the evening to avoid the heavy crowds and heat. Photography is allowed outside but not inside the prayer hall. Overall, it‚Äôs a must-visit landmark if you‚Äôre in Delhi, not just for the architecture but also for the unique sense of peace you feel here.

The Lotus Temple, located in New Delhi, India, is a stunning Baha'i House of Worship known for its unique lotus flower-inspired architecture. Completed in 1986, the temple features 27 marble-clad petals arranged in clusters of three, creating a breathtaking sight. The temple is open to people of all faiths and backgrounds, serving as a place of worship and contemplation. Its serene ambiance and beautiful gardens make it a popular tourist destination. The Lotus Temple symbolizes unity, peace, and spirituality, welcoming visitors from around the world. Its design has earned numerous accolades, and it has become an iconic symbol of India's rich cultural diversity. Visitors can explore the temple grounds, learn about the Baha'i faith, and experience a sense of tranquility amidst the bustling city. The Lotus Temple is a must-visit destination for those seeking spiritual enlightenment and architectural marvels.

Today, I visited the Lotus Temple in Delhi on my own, and although it wasn‚Äôt my first time, the experience was still special in its own way. The temple is one of the most iconic landmarks in Delhi, known for its serene ambiance and its breathtaking lotus-shaped architecture.

Unfortunately, just as I arrived, it started raining heavily, which meant I couldn‚Äôt actually enter the temple. This was my second attempt at visiting, and yet again, I had to admire it mostly from the outside. Despite that, the overall experience was memorable.

The Lotus Temple‚Äôs design is truly a sight to behold. The white marble petals form a giant lotus, symbolizing purity, peace, and unity. Even from a distance, the temple exudes a sense of calm. Surrounded by lush green gardens, the area feels like a peaceful escape from Delhi‚Äôs chaos. Standing there in the light rain, looking at the temple with droplets shimmering on the white marble, was almost meditative.

While I couldn‚Äôt step inside this time, I still cherish the quietness and the spiritual vibe that the place radiates. I also appreciated how clean and well-maintained the premises are. The sound of rain on the leaves and pathways only made the experience more soothing.

If I had to sum it up:

Pros: Stunning architecture, peaceful surroundings, serene atmosphere

Cons: Entry can be restricted during rain, so plan accordingly

Even though I haven‚Äôt yet fully explored the temple from the inside, I still find myself drawn to its energy. My love for this place grows with each visit, and I hope that on my third visit, I finally get to sit inside and experience the silence and tranquility that the Lotus Temple is famous for.

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ (4/5, only because I couldn‚Äôt enter due to rain!)

Visited the Lotus Temple in Delhi and it was an unforgettable experience. The architecture is breathtaking, shaped like a blooming lotus, and the atmosphere is incredibly peaceful. The meditation hall inside is serene and gives a sense of calmness away from the busy city. The gardens are beautifully maintained and perfect for a relaxed walk. A must-visit place in Delhi for anyone seeking peace and architectural beauty.

Visiting the Lotus Temple was a very good experience. The place is extremely well maintained with clean surroundings and excellent crowd management. Wheelchair facilities are available, which makes it convenient for elderly visitors and those with mobility challenges.

The entry process is simple and organized. Uou go through a tight security check, then walk along a beautiful green pathway leading up to the temple. Once inside, the atmosphere is truly peaceful and super silent. The devotional song and preaching echo gently through the dome, creating a serene and calming experience. Sitting there for 10‚Äì15 minutes brings a sense of inner peace.

What I really appreciated is that it‚Äôs a no fuss visit. You enter, spend quiet time in the temple, and then exit through the same walkway without unnecessary delays or commercial distractions.

Overall, I would say the Lotus Temple is a good one time visit and definitely a must see for anyone visiting Delhi. It‚Äôs not just about architecture, but also about experiencing the tranquility and spiritual calm the place offers.

placeMetadata.name: Red Fort

sources.snippet: The beautiful Red Fort (Lal Qila) was built by Shah Jahan in 1648 and served as the seat of Mughal power until 1857. This stunning structure, with its tall, red sandstone walls covers an area of more than two square kilometers, the entirety of which is crescent shaped and surrounded by a moat. The impressive main entrance, the Lahore Gate, is so named as it faces towards Lahore in Pakistan, while the even grander Delhi Gate was used by the emperor for ceremonial processions.

sources.snippet: Delhi boasts of many historical treasures and architectural marvels but the gem in its crown has to be the Red Fort. Not just a palace, the fort also served as the cultural and strategic hub for the Mughal empire.

reviews.reviewText:
The Red Fort is truly one of the most iconic landmarks of India and a must-visit in Delhi. üè∞
The architecture is stunning, with massive red sandstone walls, beautifully designed gates, and intricate carvings that showcase Mughal grandeur. Walking inside feels like stepping back into history.

The museum inside gives a good glimpse of India‚Äôs rich heritage, and the evening light & sound show is an amazing experience that brings the fort‚Äôs history to life.

‚úÖ Well-maintained in most parts
‚úÖ Good for photography üì∏
‚úÖ Great spot for history lovers and families

‚ö†Ô∏è Be prepared for crowds, especially on weekends. Carry water and wear comfortable shoes as the fort is huge and requires a lot of walking.

Overall, it‚Äôs a perfect mix of history, culture, and beauty ‚Äî a place every traveler should explore at least once!

As a foreign visitor, visiting the Red Fort early in the morning was an unforgettable experience. I arrived just before sunrise, and watching the first rays of light fall on the majestic red sandstone walls was simply breathtaking. The fort glowed in warm orange hues, and the peaceful atmosphere made it feel like time had slowed down.

The morning breeze, the quiet surroundings, and the birds chirping added to the beauty of the moment. Walking through the grand gates and exploring the historic structures inside felt like stepping back in time. I could sense the deep history and culture that this place holds.

After my visit, I felt calm, inspired, and deeply moved by the heritage of India. The Red Fort is more than just a monument ‚Äî it's a symbol of strength, beauty, and tradition. A must-visit, especially in the peaceful hours of the morning. Highly recommended!

A must-visit spot in Delhi! The Red Fort is beautifully built and very well maintained. Inside, you‚Äôll find spacious gardens, grand halls, and peaceful pathways to walk around and enjoy.

The place is clean, organized, and has good facilities for visitors. Security is well-managed, with guards around to ensure safety. Great for a relaxed outing or some quiet exploration. I had a great deep dive in history. Lot of audio visual means to experience.

When I Visit Red Fort in Delhi it‚Äôs fill me proud and amazed to watch our nation legacy that our Prime Minister addresses the nation on Independence Day.
The architecture was stunning and the place was well-maintained. It‚Äôs the place where you can watch India‚Äôs rich history, Mughal architecture, and cultural heritage. Lal Qila is the UNESCO World Heritage site. There you can walk through the structures like Diwan-i-Aam, Diwan-i-Khas, Rang Mahal, and Moti Masjid displays brilliance of Mughal architecture. The museum inside gives a deep insight into the Mughal era.
The evening light and sound show is also worth watching.
Please visit early morning or evening to avoid heat and enjoy peaceful vibes. Just at the entrance there is a market where you can buy souvenirs, perfumes, jewelry, bags, hats and many more things. Red Fort offers a blend of beauty, history, and culture that‚Äôs hard to miss. Must visit place.

The Red Fort is a grand reminder of India‚Äôs rich history and stunning Mughal architecture. Walking through its massive gates and red sandstone walls feels like stepping back in time. The fort is spread across a huge area, so be prepared for a fair amount of walking ‚Äî comfortable shoes are a must.

You can book tickets online, with options to include or skip the museum. I recommend including it if you're interested in learning more about India‚Äôs heritage. The museums are well-curated and add depth to the visit.

Inside the fort, you‚Äôll also find small shops selling souvenirs, snacks, and local crafts, which adds a lively touch to the experience. It can get a bit crowded, especially during weekends and holidays, but the vibe remains enjoyable.

Overall, it's a must-visit if you're in Delhi ‚Äî both for its historical significance and the experience of exploring one of India‚Äôs most iconic landmarks. üáÆüá≥

I have visited the Red Fort many times, and each visit feels equally special. The last time I went was on 15th August 2025 ‚Äì Independence Day, which made the experience even more memorable. Being at the fort on this day carries a unique sense of pride, as it is not only a historical monument but also the very place where India celebrates its freedom with the Prime Minister‚Äôs address and the flag hoisting ceremony.

The architecture of the fort never fails to impress me ‚Äì the majestic red sandstone walls, beautifully crafted gates, and intricately designed structures inside reflect the grandeur of the Mughal era. Walking through its corridors feels like stepping back in time and reliving the pages of history.

Apart from the monuments and historical significance, the fort also has some nice shops inside where visitors can buy souvenirs. These shops offer handicrafts, miniature replicas, and other items that make for good keepsakes to remember the trip.

Overall, the Red Fort is not just a monument but a living symbol of India‚Äôs history and heritage. Visiting it on Independence Day added an emotional and patriotic dimension to my experience, making it truly unforgettable.

We visited red fort on Saturday. We planned to watch the light and sound show in the evening but unfortunately the show was cancelled that day due to rains. Better to check if the show would take place or not before but in tickets. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend buying tickets on book my show for this show as there is no guarantee for the show to commence.

It's not just a fort, there are multiple beautiful buildings inside, so if you are planning to go here you'll have a lot of fun seeing those buildings. It was totally different from what I was expecting, which was just a red coloured fort, but this turned out to be much more exciting and beautiful than that.

reviews.reviewText:
It was an absolutely delightful place. It emanated peace and calm amidst always busy Delhi. The best time to visit will be the time for sunset according to me. The vibe of the place is immaculate. With parrots, peacocks and pigeons roaming around on the grounds, it is like an oasis of peace in the chaos of the city.

The tomb is majestic although crumbling. The entry gate itself is an example of brilliant architecture. The intricate details and designs will leave you craving for more time with those walls.

The ticket is purchased online. And it remains open till 7 pm, after that they shut it down.

Truly underrated, very less crowed but supreme in beauty. Ticket costs approx 50. Surrounded by gardens, though not very well kept due to less crowd. If you are lucky you can spot a peacock or two. Delighted to have visited this place of beauty and such architecture.

The place is clean, beautifully maintained, and surrounded by peaceful gardens. The Mughal architecture is stunning, and the calm atmosphere makes it perfect for a relaxing visit away from the city‚Äôs hustle.

Safdarjung Tomb is a really peaceful and underrated spot in Delhi. It‚Äôs not crowded at all, which makes it perfect for a quiet stroll or just relaxing with friends. The architecture is beautiful and gives off serious aesthetic vibes great for those Insta worthy pictures! If you're looking to spend a calm evening away from the city chaos, this is definitely a nice place to check out

Safdarjung Tomb is one of those monuments in Delhi that often gets overshadowed by Humayun‚Äôs Tomb or Qutub Minar, but honestly, it deserves equal attention. Located right next to Safdarjung Airport, it‚Äôs very easy to reach by metro or road. The entry tickets are affordable (cashless payment options are available), and usually the place is not too crowded, which makes the visit very relaxed.

The tomb itself is an impressive piece of Mughal architecture, built in 1754. The central dome and red sandstone structure with marble detailing look stunning, especially during early mornings or late afternoons when the sunlight falls beautifully on the arches. The gardens are laid out in the Mughal charbagh style, with symmetrical pathways and water channels, which are perfect for a peaceful walk.
What I liked most is the calm atmosphere here.

Unlike some other crowded monuments in Delhi, Safdarjung Tomb is relatively less crowded, which makes the visit more enjoyable. You can walk leisurely, admire the architectural details, and even sit under the trees to soak in the serenity.  It gives you enough space to appreciate the history and architecture. It‚Äôs also a great spot for photography, as the wide lawns, long corridors, and majestic gateways give excellent frames.

Facilities are decent. There are benches around the gardens. The ticket counter staff are polite, and the ASI has maintained the monument well. There is ample free parking. Nearby you can also visit Lodhi Garden or Khan Market for food and coffee after your tour.

Overall, Safdarjung Tomb is a hidden gem in Delhi‚Äôs heritage trail. If you are looking for history, architecture, or just a peaceful place to unwind in the middle of the city, this is a perfect spot. Highly recommended for both tourists and locals.

reviews.reviewText:
Sundar Nursery in Delhi is a hidden oasis of beauty and tranquility right in the heart of the city! This 90-acre heritage park is a perfect blend of lush greenery, stunning landscapes, and historical monuments, making it an ideal spot for nature lovers, history enthusiasts, and families alike.

What makes Sundar Nursery truly special is its peaceful ambiance‚Äîit‚Äôs a refreshing escape from Delhi‚Äôs chaos. The park is clean, well-organized, and offers plenty of shaded areas to sit and unwind. The entry fee is very reasonable, and the staff is friendly and helpful.

Whether you're looking for a quiet morning walk, a photography session, or just a place to reconnect with nature, Sundar Nursery is a must-visit. It‚Äôs one of Delhi‚Äôs best-kept secrets!

Sunder Nursery is truly one of Delhi‚Äôs hidden gems‚Äîa beautifully landscaped heritage park located right opposite the iconic Humayun‚Äôs Tomb. Spread across 90 acres, it offers a perfect blend of serene natural beauty, historical charm, and ecological richness, making it an ideal escape from the chaos of the city.

The park is designed like a mini-forest, with dense clusters of trees, flowering gardens, water bodies, and heritage monuments scattered throughout. It‚Äôs the kind of place where you can walk for hours, enjoy the chirping of birds, spot ducks gliding across the ponds, or simply sit under the shade of old trees.
