Jantar Mantarwas one of the most fascinating experiences of my trip. This remarkable site, built by Maharaja Jai Singh II in the 18th century, is not just a collection of giant instruments but a testimony to India‚Äôs advanced knowledge of astronomy and science centuries ago.

Jantar Mantar in Delhi is a historic astronomical observatory built in 1724 by Maharaja Jai Singh II of Jaipur. It consists of 13 large stone instruments designed to measure time, track celestial bodies, and predict astronomical events with the naked eye. Located near Connaught Place, it was created to improve the accuracy of calendars and planetary movement predictions in the 18th century. The observatory showcases India's rich scientific heritage and ancient knowledge of astronomy, with notable instruments such as the huge sundial Samrat Yantra. It is a popular tourist spot, open from 6 AM to 6 PM daily, and easily accessible by metro. The name "Jantar Mantar" means "instrument for calculation" in Sanskrit.

Address: Sansad Marg, near Connaught Place, New Delhi
Entry Fee: ‚Çπ15 for Indians, ‚Çπ200 for foreigners.

Jantar Mantar offers a fascinating glimpse into India's past scientific achievements and is a must-visit for history and astronomy enthusiasts.

Overview
Jantar Mantar in New Delhi is an astronomical observatory built in the 18th century. It is a testament to the scientific and architectural ingenuity of the past, consisting of a collection of colossal masonry instruments used for astronomical observations. It's one of five such observatories built by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II of Jaipur, who was a passionate astronomer and a patron of science. While it may not serve its original scientific purpose today due to the surrounding tall buildings, it remains a fascinating historical and architectural site.
Historical Significance
The Delhi Jantar Mantar was the first of five observatories constructed by Maharaja Jai Singh II between 1724 and 1730, with the others located in Jaipur, Ujjain, Varanasi, and Mathura. He was commissioned by Mughal emperor Muhammad Shah to revise the astronomical tables of the time and improve the accuracy of the calendar. Jai Singh II believed that the smaller, brass instruments used by astronomers were not precise enough, so he built these large, fixed masonry instruments to achieve greater accuracy. The name "Jantar Mantar" is derived from Sanskrit, with "Yantra" meaning instrument and "Mantra" meaning formula or calculation, effectively translating to "instruments for measuring the harmony of the heavens."
Architecture and Instruments
The architecture of Jantar Mantar is striking, with its geometric, sculpture-like instruments that are both functional and visually impressive. The complex is an open-air observatory with several key instruments, each designed for a specific astronomical purpose.
* Samrat Yantra: This is the most prominent instrument, a massive triangular sundial (the "Supreme Instrument"). It was used to measure time with remarkable accuracy, with a large gnomon (the arm of the sundial) and a curved scale on which the shadow would fall.
* Mishra Yantra: This "mixed instrument" is a combination of five instruments and was used to determine the shortest and longest days of the year. It could also be used to find out the precise time of noon in different cities around the world.
* Ram Yantra: Two large cylindrical structures with open tops, designed for measuring the altitude and azimuth of celestial bodies.
* Jai Prakash Yantra: A pair of concave hemispherical sundials used to align the position of stars to markings on the instrument's surface.
Visitor Experience and Review
Jantar Mantar offers a unique experience for visitors, blending science, history, and art.
* Atmosphere: The site is a tranquil green space in the middle of a bustling city, offering a peaceful environment for exploration. The instruments themselves have a sculptural quality that is very appealing.
* Educational Value: For those interested in astronomy and ancient science, the complex is an educational marvel. It provides a tangible glimpse into the scientific knowledge and dedication of 18th-century Indian astronomers. Guides (sometimes available) or informational plaques can help explain the function of each instrument.
* Photography: The striking shapes and colors of the instruments against the backdrop of the sky make Jantar Mantar a popular spot for photographers.
* Accessibility: Jantar Mantar is located on Sansad Marg near Connaught Place, making it easily accessible by Delhi Metro (the nearest station is Patel Chowk or Rajiv Chowk). Entry fees are low for Indian citizens and a bit higher for foreigners.
In summary, Jantar Mantar is a compelling destination for anyone with an interest in history, science, and unique architecture. While its functionality has been compromised by modern buildings, its historical significance and the sheer brilliance of its design make it a worthwhile visit for a glimpse into India's rich scientific past.

Jantar Mantar in Delhi is an extraordinary observatory constructed by Maharaja Jai Singh II. It stands as a testament to the scientific and astronomical genius of 18th-century India. The complex, consisting of monumental instruments, was built with the purpose of compiling accurate astronomical tables and predicting the movements of celestial bodies, showcasing a sophisticated understanding of the cosmos long before modern technology.
‚ÄãThe observatory's key instruments, like the massive Samrat Yantra (Supreme Instrument), function as an enormous sundial, capable of measuring time with impressive accuracy. The Jai Prakash Yantra, or "light of victory," is another unique design, consisting of hollowed hemispheres used to observe the position of the sun. These structures, along with others, were meticulously designed to track the sun, moon, and planets.
‚ÄãFor the modern tourist, Jantar Mantar is more than just a collection of old buildings; it's an immersive experience. The sheer scale and architectural beauty of the instruments are breathtaking. You can walk among these large, geometric forms, marveling at how they were engineered to perform complex calculations. It offers a tangible connection to history and a sense of wonder at the ingenuity of ancient astronomers.
‚ÄãVisiting Jantar Mantar provides valuable insights into India's rich scientific heritage. It‚Äôs a perfect spot for anyone interested in science, history, or simply looking for a peaceful and visually stunning place to explore. It‚Äôs an educational and inspiring journey that highlights the timeless human pursuit of understanding our place in the universe.

sources.snippet: The Crafts Museum-officially named the National Handicrafts and Handlooms Museum, New Delhi-displays a wide variety of traditional crafts from across India. Tucked away near Pragati Maidan, the National Crafts Museum & Hastkala Academy is one of Delhi‚Äôs most enriching and underrated cultural experiences. Far more than just a museum, it‚Äôs a vibrant space where India‚Äôs rich craft heritage comes alive.

The outdoor area features life-sized traditional huts from various Indian regions ‚Äî tribal homes from the Northeast, mud cottages from Gujarat and Rajasthan, and more. Each is decorated with local art and architecture, giving visitors a real sense of rural India.

Inside, the galleries showcase an incredible range of handicrafts and textiles. From Pashmina shawls of Kashmir to Kanjeevaram silks, Phulkari, Chikankari, Bandhani, and more, the museum takes you on a journey through India‚Äôs diverse textile traditions. There are also stunning displays of pottery, woodwork, tribal art, and metalwork.

A peaceful library within the complex houses books and rare research material on Indian crafts, textiles, and folk traditions‚Äîperfect for students and art lovers.

The museum also hosts several craft shops, where you can buy authentic, locally made handlooms, garments, jewelry, and decorative items. Many are sold by artisans themselves, making your purchase directly beneficial to the communities.

placeMetadata.name: National Rail Museum

sources.snippet: Spread across 10 acres, the National Rail Museum houses more than 30 locomotives and several old carriages, most of them quite rare. All told, more than 140 years of Indian railway history has been preserved on this fascinating site, including an engine built in 1885 and the Fairy Queen steam engine from 1855. Other highlights include several unique items, such as a collection of saloon cars belonging to the country's once powerful Maharajas, including the teak carriage of the Maharaja of Mysore, covered with ivory; the cabin of the Prince of Wales from 1876; and the carriage in which the ashes of Gandhi were carried after his assassination in 1948.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Delhi & New Delhi

sources.snippet: A very significant museum in the history of India is the National Rail Museum in Delhi. It is situated in Chanakyapuri with a focus on the rail heritage India had been possessing. It was opened on February 1st 1977.

placeMetadata.description: Indian railway museum featuring historical exhibits & artefacts, including a 1855 steam locomotive.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The National Rail Museum in Delhi is a paradise for train enthusiasts, offering a captivating journey through the rich history and heritage of Indian railways. With over 100 real exhibits, including a remarkable 1855 steam locomotive, the museum showcases antique train furniture, railway equipment, historical photographs, and memorabilia. Visitors can marvel at the Fairy Queen, the world's oldest operating steam engine, and enjoy rides on a toy train around the museum grounds.

reviews.reviewText: Visiting the National Rail Museum in Delhi with my family was an amazing experience! The museum beautifully showcases the rich history of Indian Railways with its impressive collection of vintage locomotives, carriages, and informative exhibits. The highlight of our visit was definitely the joy ride ‚Äî it was so much fun for both kids and adults! Riding on the toy train around the museum grounds gave us a wonderful view of the entire place and added a special charm to the visit. I highly recommend the joy ride to everyone ‚Äî it's a must-try! The staff was friendly, the place was well-maintained, and there were plenty of interactive activities for children. Overall, a fantastic day out for the whole family!

Good outing for kids . Today, 22Jun25,only joy ride, as fun activities is operational.  Museum is good for learning  experience.  Decent restaurant. Parking area was enough as I reached early. Full by the time I left. Ticket cost differs on weekends day and weekends

It was a nice experience visiting the museum and enjoying the joy train. The museum reflects our railways' history from the very beginning till now and has a food stall, as well. A must go place with your friends and family.

The National Rail Museum in Delhi is a must-visit for railway exam aspirants and history lovers! üöÜ Packed with fascinating facts, real-life train models, and a fun quiz section, it makes learning about Indian Railways engaging and visual.

If you're preparing for RRB NTPC, Group D, or SSC exams ‚Äî this place helps clarify key railway concepts with ease. The heritage engines, exhibits, and interactive zones bring both history and present rail systems to life.

Highly recommended for students, families, and anyone curious about India‚Äôs rail legacy. Don't miss the toy train ride!

The National Rail Museum in Delhi is a decent place to visit once, especially if you have kids who are curious about trains. The museum has a huge collection of old engines, coaches, and even some rare locomotives that show the history of Indian Railways. It‚Äôs quite informative and gives a nostalgic vibe, but the overall experience feels more like a display gallery than an interactive attraction.

For children, it can be exciting in the beginning because of the mini toy train ride and some outdoor exhibits, but apart from that, there isn‚Äôt much in terms of fun or activities. Adults may find it a bit monotonous after walking around for a while, since most things are to ‚Äúsee and read,‚Äù not really to ‚Äúdo.‚Äù The maintenance in some parts could be better, and the place feels slightly outdated.

If you are looking for an entertaining day out, this may not be the best choice. However, if your kids are interested in trains or you enjoy railway history, then it‚Äôs worth a short visit. Overall, it‚Äôs an ok-ok experience ‚Äî educational for kids, nostalgic for parents, but not something you‚Äôd return to again and again.

The National Rail Museum is a great place for children they‚Äôll really enjoy their visit. Ticket prices are lower on weekdays and higher on weekends and government holidays. Currently, only the joy train is operational, and there are limited swings or play areas for kids.

The museum itself is quite interesting, with plenty to see about the history of Indian Railways how it all began and how far it has come. The canteen has a decent ambience; if you're hungry, you can try the food, but it‚Äôs just average in taste. Parking is available at a fee of Rs. 10 per hour, managed by the MCD.

Main Museum with miniature is well maintained. Car Parking is very well managed. Only Joy train is operational currently, for which you have to buy an extra ticket as it's not included in the main entrance ticket. Toilets were clean (used the one that is near the auditorium and not at the entrance) but definitely needs an upgradation. Prices at the Souvenir shop is also ok ‚Çπ50-100 for fridge magnets etc.

The National Rail museum is a very fascinating place to visit with kids. They get to learn about the rich history of Indian railways. The museum showcases a wide range of trains and its parts and tickets used earlier. Don‚Äôt miss the toy train ride. When we went only one ride was functional, that was a little disappointing.
Lastly the food of the cafeteria was too yummy . We ordered Dhosa and we loved it

reviews.reviewText: It's one of the best place to explore around South-West of Delhi. It has calm and pleasing atmosphere, and well maintained surroundings. You can go there for evening strolls, beautiful photographs with Qutub Minar as your background. It has Cafe there as well. The ticket was 50 for each Indian.

I visited this place as part of a heritage walk, and it was an incredible experience. The tour was well-organized and very informative. To enter the park, you need to buy a ticket on-site. Inside, you'll find a beautiful tomb, a serene water lake, a cozy caf√©, and a museum that adds depth to the historical significance of the site. The highlight for me was the stunning sunset view!

Mehrauli Archaeological Park is a beautiful historical site. To get here, take the metro to Qutub Minar station, then walk about 1 km to reach the park. Spanning over 200 acres, it‚Äôs best suited for those who enjoy walking and exploring.

The park is home to several notable monuments like Jamali-Kamali Mosque and Tomb, Rajon Ki Baoli, Quli Khan‚Äôs Tomb, Caf√© Stoned, and more. There‚Äôs an entry fee of ‚Çπ50 per person at the Quli Tomb entrance.

The area is lush with greenery and very peaceful ‚Äî the only sound you‚Äôll hear is an airplane passing overhead every couple of minutes. From here, you can also enjoy a great view of the Qutub Minar. The place isn‚Äôt very crowded, likely because most visitors head straight to Qutub Minar, so you can explore in peace.

It‚Äôs a lovely spot to spend the day with your loved ones, and it‚Äôs also kid-friendly. I had a really nice experience here ‚ù§Ô∏è

Mehrauli Archaeological Park is a hidden gem near Qutub Minar Metro Station. The park is full of old monuments, tombs, and ruins spread across green areas. Walking here feels like stepping back in time, away from the busy city. It‚Äôs peaceful, less crowded, and great for history lovers or a quiet stroll. Some places need better care, but the charm of ancient Delhi is still alive.

I have visited the place on 13/8/25.From my personal point of view this place offer many things.From ancient day monuments to modern day form of renovation.The standing fort, the tomb of Muhammad Quli Khan is a testament of time and longevity.The symbol of peace and tranquility,calmness and still remains significant.The place offers wide open space for leisure walk,one can come and meditate in the midst of the greenery and peaceful environment.You can also see the Qutub Minar from this point, it's a beautiful sight to behold from here.I will recommend this place for those who would like to go for quiet date and people who loves to read in very quiet environment.It has cafe space so you can also relax and chill while you can enjoy the view at the same time.

I recently explored the Mehrauli Archaeological Park alone, and it turned out to be a wonderful mix of history, peace, and discovery. Spread across a huge area right next to Qutub Minar, the park is filled with ancient monuments, tombs, and ruins that make you feel like you‚Äôve stepped back in time.

Walking in, I was amazed at how quiet and green the place was compared to the busy streets outside. Since I went alone, I could just wander at my own pace, taking random paths and stumbling upon old structures. From the stepwell (Rajon ki Baoli) to historic tombs like Jamali Kamali, every spot had its own charm. The carvings, arches, and weathered stones told silent stories of centuries gone by.

What I liked most was the combination of nature and history. Birds, trees, and wide open spaces made it feel more like a peaceful retreat than a typical tourist site. At some places, I was the only one around, which added a sense of calm and gave me time to sit quietly, click pictures, and just imagine how life must have been here hundreds of years ago.

The park isn‚Äôt as crowded as other monuments, so it‚Äôs perfect for a solo outing if you want both space and history. Of course, it‚Äôs good to carry water and wear comfortable shoes since there‚Äôs a lot of walking. Overall, my solo visit to Mehrauli Archaeological Park was refreshing‚Äîa hidden gem where Delhi‚Äôs history and nature meet beautifully.

Mehrauli Archaeological Park is a hidden jewel‚Äîvalued for its layered history, vast greenery, and quiet ambiance. It's ideal for exploring heritage without the typical touristic crowds.

Plan 3‚Äì5 hours, especially if you want to explore remote corners and stepwells (which are off the main trail) Minimal crowds compared to other Delhi landmarks; photo-friendly and tranquil.

Serene, shaded gardens and trails perfect for walking or relaxingthe park‚Äôs calm and green atmosphere‚Äîa rare oasis of nature in the city. You‚Äôll spot birds, squirrels, shady trails, and occasional fountains, which offer nice photo opportunities at sunset or morning light.

Spread across approximately 200 acres, Mehrauli Archaeological Park is adjacent to the Qutub Minar complex and houses over 100 monuments spanning nearly a millennium‚Äîfrom the Tomar, Khalji, Tughlaq, Lodi, Mughal, to British eras .
If the weather is good, just go to this place and experience amazing architecture of mughal era and learn less known facts. The cafe (Stone cafe) is also nice next to a small pond.

Hauz Khas Complex, located in South Delhi, India, is a historic site renowned for its architectural significance and vibrant surroundings.‚Äã

History: The name "Hauz Khas" is derived from Persian, where 'Hauz' means "water tank" and 'Khas' denotes "royal," translating to "Royal Tank." This reservoir was originally constructed by Alauddin Khilji during his reign from 1296 to 1316 to supply water to the inhabitants of Siri, the second city of Delhi. Later, during Firuz Shah Tughlaq's rule (1351‚Äì1388), the tank was desilted, and several significant structures were added around it, including a madrasa (Islamic seminary), a mosque, and Firuz Shah's own tomb. These additions transformed the area into a prominent center for Islamic education and architecture. ‚Äã

Monuments and Structures: The complex houses several notable structures:‚Äã

Madrasa: An Islamic learning center established by Firuz Shah Tughlaq, showcasing Indo-Islamic architectural styles.‚Äã

Mosque: A place of worship adjacent to the madrasa, reflecting the architectural aesthetics of the Tughlaq dynasty.‚Äã

Firuz Shah's Tomb: The final resting place of Sultan Firuz Shah Tughlaq, centrally located within the complex.‚Äã

Pavilions and Cenotaphs: Scattered throughout the gardens, these structures add to the historical ambiance of the site.‚Äã

Chor Minar: Known as the "Tower of Thieves," historically believed to have displayed the heads of executed thieves as a deterrent during the Khilji dynasty. ‚Äã

Visiting Hours: The Hauz Khas Complex is open daily from 10:30 AM to 7:00 PM. It is advisable to visit during early morning or late afternoon hours to avoid the midday heat and to experience the site in pleasant lighting conditions. ‚Äã

Facilities: Adjacent to the complex is the Deer Park, a well-maintained green space home to spotted deer, peacocks, rabbits, and various bird species. The park offers walking trails, a rose garden, and a duck pond, providing a serene environment for relaxation. Additionally, the surrounding Hauz Khas Village has evolved into a hub for art galleries, boutiques, cafes, and restaurants, blending historical charm with contemporary culture. ‚Äã

How to Reach from New Delhi Railway Station and Indira Gandhi International Airport:

From New Delhi Railway Station: Hauz Khas is approximately 12 kilometers away. You can take the Yellow Line of the Delhi Metro from New Delhi Station to Hauz Khas Metro Station. Alternatively, taxis and auto-rickshaws are readily available.‚Äã

From Indira Gandhi International Airport: The complex is about 16 kilometers from the airport. Travelers can use app-based cab services or airport taxis for a direct journey. For a more economical option, take the Airport Express Line to New Delhi Metro Station, then transfer to the Yellow Line towards Hauz Khas. ‚Äã

Best Season to Visit: The ideal time to explore Hauz Khas Complex is during the cooler months, from October to March. During this period, the weather is pleasant, making it comfortable to walk around and fully appreciate the historical and cultural offerings of the area. ‚Äã

Hauz Khas Complex offers a unique blend of Delhi's rich historical heritage and its dynamic modern culture, making it a must-visit destination for both history enthusiasts and casual travelers.

We visited Hauz Khas Complex in New Delhi in December 2024. It indeed serves as a wonderful reminder of Delhi‚Äôs rich history.

The complex traces its origins to the 13th century during the reign of Alauddin Khilji. The term ‚ÄòHauz Khas‚Äô translates to ‚ÄòRoyal Tank‚Äô in Persian, referring to the large water reservoir built to supply water to the city of Siri. Later, Firoz Shah Tughlaq restored the tank and added significant structures, including a madrasa (Islamic seminary), mosque, and his own tomb .

You can easily spend more than half a day exploring the different structures, and some areas make great spots for photos. The history is evident here in the madrasa and Firoz Shah‚Äôs tomb.

The serene Hauz Khas lake serves as a wonderful accompaniment to the complex. The complex is open everyday from 10:30am to 7pm.

Nearest metro station: Hauz Khas

Entry fees: 20 rupees for Indian Nationals and 250 rupees for foreign tourists

Hauz Khas Fort has always felt like a hidden gem to me, tucked away behind the lively chaos of Hauz Khas Village, yet offering a sudden and surreal calm as soon as I step inside. The crumbling stone walls, ancient domes, and narrow stairways whisper stories of centuries gone by, and I often find myself imagining the lives that once unfolded within them. The view from the top‚Äîoverlooking the peaceful green waters of the reservoir and the surrounding Deer Park‚Äîis especially breathtaking during sunset, when everything is bathed in warm golden light. I love how the fort blends history with serenity; it's a place where I can just sit, reflect, and escape the city without ever really leaving it. Each visit feels personal and grounding, like the fort holds space for my thoughts alongside its history.

As well as the main Gurudwara Temple, you‚Äôll find a Holy River in the middle of the complex called the ‚ÄúSarovar‚Äù.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled just 5 kilometers from the bustling heart of New Delhi, Gurudwara Bangla Sahib stands as a beacon of peace and spirituality. This revered Sikh gurdwara is deeply connected to the legacy of Guru Har Krishan, the eighth Sikh guru, who visited in 1664. Originally constructed in 1783 by General Sardar Bhagel Singh during Mughal Emperor Shah Alam II's reign, it was one of nine Sikh shrines he built that year.
placeMetadata.address: Hanuman Road Area, Connaught Place, New Delhi, Delhi 110001, India

reviews.reviewText:
Today, I had the privilege of visiting Gurudwara Bangla Sahib in Delhi, and the experience was nothing short of beautiful. The moment I stepped into the premises, a sense of calm washed over me. The golden dome glistening in the sunlight, the sacred sarovar (pond) reflecting the sky, and the soft hymns of kirtan created an atmosphere of deep peace and devotion.

One of the highlights of my visit was partaking in the langar‚Äîthe community kitchen that serves free meals to everyone, regardless of background, religion, or status. The langar hall was filled with a sense of unity and humility as people from all walks of life sat together in rows to share a simple, yet soul-satisfying meal. The volunteers served with warmth and smiles, and there was a profound beauty in the spirit of seva (selfless service).

The meal itself was wholesome and comforting‚Äîfreshly made chapatis, dal, sabzi, and kheer. But beyond the food, it was the feeling of gratitude and togetherness that made it so memorable. Watching people come together, serve, and share in harmony was deeply touching.

After the langar, I spent some time near the sarovar, sitting quietly and soaking in the serenity of the place. The soft chants in the background and the sight of devotees engaged in prayer and service left me with a sense of inner peace.

My visit to Bangla Sahib was not just about sightseeing‚Äîit was a spiritual experience. It reminded me of the values of humility, equality, and compassion. I left with a full heart, a calm mind, and a renewed appreciation for the power of community and faith.

reviews.reviewText: The Garden of Five Senses is located around 3 km from Saket Metro Station. Though officially a public garden, in reality it feels more like a quiet forest space. It‚Äôs most popular among couples looking for privacy and peaceful surroundings. The inner areas of the garden are mostly occupied by couples, and you‚Äôll find very few families or groups there. Families that do visit usually stay near the outer lawns or picnic areas, unaware of the deeper sections. For solo visitors, the garden is great if you're looking for greenery, silence, or a nature walk. The place is well-maintained and entry is affordable. Just know in advance ‚Äî this is more of a couple-friendly spot than a typical family park.

The Garden of Five Senses is beautifully landscaped and well-kept, offering a peaceful escape from the city. However, please note: this garden is primarily a popular hangout spot for couples. Almost every corner has couples spending private moments, which might make it uncomfortable for families or solo visitors looking for a quiet stroll.

üéü Ticketing:
There is no online booking facility ‚Äì tickets are sold only at the gate and strictly by cash. Entry fee is ‚Çπ35 per person. Be sure to carry exact change, especially ‚Çπ5 coins or notes, as the staff often refuse to give smaller denominations and may ask you to bring change yourself.

‚úÖ Pros:

Beautiful, green, and well-maintained

Great for photography and nature walks

Calm atmosphere if you're visiting as a couple

‚ùå Cons:

Not suitable for family outings

Public display of affection is common

No digital payment or online booking

The Garden of Five Senses in Delhi is a peaceful retreat with lush greenery, themed gardens, and artistic installations‚Äîperfect for nature lovers and photographers. reviews.reviewText:
Visiting Gurudwara Bangla Sahib is a deeply spiritual experience. The moment you step in, you're enveloped in peace and devotion. The divine atmosphere, Gurbani recitals, and Langar service create a sense of oneness with the Divine.
This revered Sikh shrine in New Delhi is a must-visit. Its cleanliness and serenity are truly remarkable. Do visit at night when it's beautifully lit up. And don't forget to savour the delicious 'Prasad' ( Langer) !

Gurudwara Shri Bangla Sahib Ji is truly one of the most serene and spiritually uplifting places in New Delhi. The moment you step through the gates, the chaotic noise of the city fades away, replaced by the calming sounds of kirtan (devotional music) echoing through the air. The golden dome glistening under the sky and the peaceful Sarovar (holy pond) create a deeply tranquil atmosphere that touches your soul.

The entire premises are immaculately maintained by devoted volunteers. One of the most humbling experiences is sitting in the Langar Hall, where a free, delicious vegetarian meal is served to all, regardless of caste, creed, or background. It‚Äôs a true example of humanity, equality, and service.

I was especially moved by the kindness and discipline of the sewadars (volunteers). From guiding visitors to helping with the head covers and offering water and food, their dedication is inspiring. The museum and the library within the complex are also worth a visit for those interested in Sikh history and values.

Whether you're religious or not, a visit to Gurudwara Bangla Sahib will leave you feeling calm, grateful, and more connected. Highly recommended for locals and tourists alike.

It is located in a well accessed area..clearly visible from the main road. Visit it for its beauty that's a must see, for offering your prayers & for providing Sewa (your Services). There is peace, discipline & serenity irrespective of the temple being full of people. Must visit. üôè‚ú®

Visiting Gurudwara Bangla Sahib is a deeply spiritual and humbling experience. The moment you step inside, you are embraced by an overwhelming sense of peace and devotion. The divine atmosphere, the soulful recitation of Gurbani, and the sight of devotees selflessly serving in the Langar hall create a feeling of pure oneness with the Divine.

The Sarovar (holy pond) adds to the serenity, and simply sitting by its side brings a sense of inner calm and reflection. Gurudwara Bangla Sahib stands not just as a place of worship, but as a living symbol of compassion, humility, and the timeless teachings of Sikhism.

It is a place where the soul feels light, where the heart finds hope, and where faith deepens effortlessly. Truly a sanctuary of divine love and grace.

Gurudwara Bangla Sahib is one of those few places which stays with you long after you leave. As soon as you step inside the gates, all the noise of Delhi seems to fade away and you get enveloped by a sense of calm. The golden dome of Bangla Sahib Gurudwara shines royally along with the hymns that are being sung. The kohinoor of Delhi pauses for one to take that deep breath and relax.

This place is special because of how everyone is treated equally. Everyone can enter the community kitchen and serve themselves food 24*7, there are no restrictions. Watching the hardworking volunteers tirelessly chop vegetables, cook, serve and clean is moving to say the least. Dip your feet in the sarovar and the rest of the world gets blindsided by the quiet charm of the Gurudwara.

In the night, this Gurudwara serves a different purpose. All the prayers from the bangla combined with the splashes from the sarovar can be heard clearly. The marble monument gets illuminated and the water reflects all the night lights. For hours, one can sit without overthinking and relax.

People come here for many different reasons, but everyone is bound to get at least a little bit tired. All of this Islam and serenity, along with you are bound to feel at least just a bit weary at one time, and Bangla will take care of you at that moment.

Rather, it contributes to the sensation that you are entering into something larger than yourself. Your reasons of faith, curiosity, or simply wanting to take a moment of silence will ensure you leave with its sense of calm.

Gurudwara Bangla Sahib is not just a religious place‚Äîit's an experience of peace, humility, and spiritual calm right in the heart of Delhi. Whether you're religious or not, a visit here truly touches your heart.

The marble architecture, gold-plated dome, and peaceful Sarovar add to the beauty of the place. You‚Äôll also see many people sitting quietly, meditating, or simply soaking in the positive energy.

Personally, I really enjoy coming here, and I almost always visit alone. Sitting quietly by the Sarovar (holy pond) and listening to the peaceful bhajans (hymns) brings a deep sense of calm. It‚Äôs a beautiful place to pause, reflect, and simply be present. üßò‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüíõ

Everything here‚Äîfrom the langar (community kitchen) to the volunteers cleaning the floor‚Äîspeaks of seva (selfless service) and equality. No matter your background, everyone is welcomed warmly and fed with love. üçõüôè

Quick Tips üìù:

üß¢ Head covering is compulsory for everyone‚Äîscarves are available at the entrance.
üë£ Shoes are to be removed before entering (there‚Äôs a proper shoe counter)
üïí Best time to visit: Early morning or evening for a peaceful vibe.
üç≤ Don‚Äôt miss the langar‚Äîsimple food, full of love and meaning.
üì∏ Photography is not allowed inside.
üíß You can also drink or take some holy water from the Sarovar.
üõï There‚Äôs also a small museum inside about Sikh history, worth a quick visit.

üìç Nearest Metro Station: Shivaji Stadium (Airport Express) or Patel Chowk (Yellow Line)‚Äîboth are walkable

Try coming via Patel Nagar Metro Station‚Äîthe Sikh community there offers free rides to Bangla Sahib and cold drinking water to visitors. It's a kind and thoughtful service that reflects the true spirit of seva üôèüöê

Final Thought üí¨:
Bangla Sahib is more than a historical or religious site‚Äîit‚Äôs a place to slow down, reflect, and feel connected. You don‚Äôt need to understand everything to feel the peace here. Even a short visit can leave you with a calm mind and a warm heart. üå∏‚ú®

reviews.reviewText: Hauz Khas Fort is a peaceful historic site in South Delhi, dating back to the 13th century. Overlooking a serene lake, the fort features ancient ruins, a madrasa, mosque, and tomb built in Indo-Islamic style. It‚Äôs perfect for a quiet stroll, photography, or watching the sunset. Entry is free, and the site is open from sunrise to sunset. While there‚Äôs limited signage, the atmosphere is rich with history. Located next to Hauz Khas Village, you can explore cafes and shops nearby. Accessibility is limited due to uneven terrain, and there are no restrooms on-site. Despite minor maintenance issues, it's a great spot for history lovers or anyone seeking calm in the city.

Peaceful, historic, and unexpectedly scenic ‚Äì Hauz Khas Fort is one of my favorite hidden corners in Delhi. Nestled behind the lively Hauz Khas Village, the fort offers a calm escape with stunning views of the lake and crumbling stone architecture that tells stories from the 14th century.

Great spot for:

Quiet walks

Golden hour photos

Reading or reflecting

Exploring old ruins at your own pace

It‚Äôs free to enter and usually not too crowded, especially on weekday mornings or evenings. The view of the lake from the back of the fort is absolutely worth the visit. Afterward, you can hop into one of the nearby cafes for a coffee or snack‚Äîeverything is within walking distance.

Only downside: the fort could be cleaner in places. Some graffiti and litter take away from the beauty a bit.

But overall, a must-visit if you're into history, peaceful vibes, or just want a break from the usual Delhi hustle.

üì∏ Tip: Bring a camera‚Äîthe light near sunset is magical here.

Hauz Khas Fort is a beautiful place with a lovely atmosphere. From here, you can also enjoy views of the Deer Park and the lake, which makes the visit more peaceful and scenic. The fort itself is not very large, but it‚Äôs still worth visiting for its charm, history, and surroundings. A good spot for photography, walks, and spending some quiet time.

Hauz Khas Fort: A Tranquil Historical Escape
Nestled within the vibrant Hauz Khas Village lies the serene Hauz Khas Fort, offering a refreshing contrast to typical tourist destinations. For a nominal entry fee of ‚Çπ20 for adults (children enter free), visitors can immerse themselves in a remarkably calm atmosphere with fewer crowds.
The fort's picturesque setting is enhanced by a beautiful lake that borders its grounds, providing a tranquil backdrop to the historical structures. Situated within Hauz Khas Village itself, the fort benefits from the availability of numerous hotels and guest houses in the vicinity, making it a convenient location for travelers.
Stepping outside the fort's walls, one is immediately struck by the contrasting energy of Hauz Khas Village. This area pulsates with a modern, lively culture, boasting numerous pubs, nightclubs, and restaurants in close proximity to the historical site. Interestingly, some of these establishments offer captivating views of the fort and the adjacent lake, providing a unique ambiance. An evening spent here, perhaps enjoying live music, promises a distinctive experience.
In terms of its structure, Hauz Khas Fort remains in commendable condition, housing the tombs of ancient kings and offering a tangible connection to the region's rich past. It stands as a testament to history, providing a peaceful retreat alongside the contemporary buzz of the surrounding village.

Hauz Khas Fort is one of the most beautiful and historic spots in Delhi. It perfectly blends history with a peaceful atmosphere, making it a must-visit for anyone who enjoys heritage sites. The fort‚Äôs ruins, combined with the large lake, create a very scenic and photogenic environment. If you are into history, architecture, or photography, this place will not disappoint.

Walking through the old tombs, mosques, and broken walls gives you a glimpse of Delhi‚Äôs past. The view during the evening is especially breathtaking, when the sunlight reflects on the lake and the whole place feels calm and serene. The surrounding Hauz Khas Village area also has plenty of trendy caf√©s and restaurants, so you can easily spend a relaxed evening here after exploring the fort.

That being said, the site could definitely use better maintenance. Some walls are defaced with scribbles, and cleanliness is not always up to the mark. These issues take away a little from the overall charm of the monument.

Still, Hauz Khas Fort remains a peaceful escape from Delhi‚Äôs busy streets. It‚Äôs a great place to spend a few hours with friends, family, or even alone if you just want some quiet time with history and nature.

placeMetadata.name: Swaminarayan Akshardham

sources.snippet: Although only recently completed (it opened in 2007), the splendid Hindu Akshardham temple looks like it could be centuries old. Festooned with intricate and elaborate carvings, this magnificent building attracts countless visitors for its majestic beauty. Highlights include the stunning 43-meter-high main monument with its rich carvings of animals, plants, gods, dancers, and musicians, all made from pink sandstone and marble.

placeMetadata.description: Over 11,000 artisans worked on this lavishly decorated Hindu temple complex inaugurated in 2005.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Swaminarayan Akshardham, inaugurated in 2005, is a breathtaking Hindu temple complex that showcases the rich tapestry of Indian culture and spirituality through its stunning architecture and artistry. Constructed over five years without steel, this remarkable site spans more than 32 acres and features exquisite materials like pink sandstone and white marble sourced from across India. The centerpiece is an impressive Mandir adorned with intricate carvings, including 20,000 stone figures representing India's revered saints and sages.

Akshardham Temple is stunning with its grand architecture and peaceful atmosphere. The carvings are beautiful, the gardens are well maintained, and the evening water show is a must-watch. Phones and cameras aren‚Äôt allowed inside, but the experience is unforgettable.

July 5, 2025 ‚Äì 2nd day in Delhi

Our tour guide brought us to Akshardham, a grand Hindu spiritual and cultural complex known for its stunning architecture and peaceful atmosphere. I had heard so much about it and was glad to finally see it in person.

We left all our belongings‚Äîincluding phones, cameras, and bags‚Äîin the car, as absolutely no electronics are allowed inside. The rules are very strict, and there are multiple security checks. While I understand the need for security, the staff at the entry checkpoints came across as quite rude. The pat downs felt unnecessarily rough, which made the start of our visit a bit uncomfortable.

The structures themselves are breathtaking. The intricate carvings, massive domes, and the scale of the complex are truly impressive. It‚Äôs clear that an incredible amount of work and devotion went into creating this space. But it was extremely crowded, and the overwhelming number of people made it hard to enjoy the beauty. At times it felt almost suffocating, especially under the intense afternoon heat.

My five and seven year old were just not able to take much from the experience. Even though I pointed out the beautiful details and architecture, they were too hot and tired to engage. We had looked forward to exploring the grounds more, but between the crowd and the heat, we had to cut it short.

There are definitely peaceful corners here‚Äîfountains, gardens, and shaded walkways‚Äîbut overall, the experience felt more hectic than calming. I can see how it could be meaningful on a cooler, quieter day, but for us, it was a bit too much.

Beautifully well maintained..spiritual cultural place.Electronic items are not allowed inside. We can have the locker facility. The structure and the intricate carving is wonderfully done. Clean , well maintained, peaceful place.

Tughlaqabad Fort, a 14th-century marvel in Delhi, is a must-visit for history buffs! Built by Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq in 1321, this massive fort with its towering stone walls and 13 remaining gates showcases Tughlaq dynasty architecture. Highlights include the underground passages, rainwater tanks, and the nearby red sandstone mausoleum. The fort‚Äôs rocky hill setting and eerie legend of a Sufi saint‚Äôs curse add mystique, though it was abandoned just six years after construction. Open 7 AM‚Äì5 PM, entry is INR 20 for Indians, INR 200‚Äì250 for foreigners. Easily reachable via Tughlaqabad Metro Station, it‚Äôs a captivating, slightly haunting glimpse into Delhi‚Äôs past. Ghiyasuddins tomb is just adjacent. North Western part of the fort is not open to tourists. Limited car Parking available.

Situation in the beautiful green serenity of Delhi that is day by day being eaten away by illegal construction.

Tughlaqabad Fort is a site that commands respect for its sheer scale and historical significance. Built by Ghiyas-ud-din Tughlaq in the 14th century, the fort's imposing walls and remnants of a once-grand city offer a powerful sense of history. It's a great spot for a peaceful walk, away from the usual chaos of Delhi's more popular monuments. You can spend a good amount of time exploring the vast, sprawling ruins and imagining what the city might have been like in its prime. The views from the top are also quite good, providing a nice panoramic of the surrounding area.
‚ÄãHowever, the experience is decidedly "average" due to its current condition. Much of the fort is in ruins, and not in a well-preserved way.

Recently, I had the opportunity to visit Tughlakabad Fort in New Delhi, and it turned out to be an unforgettable experience that blended history, architecture, and a sense of timeless grandeur.

Built in 1321 by Ghiyas-ud-din Tughlaq, the founder of the Tughlaq dynasty, this fort was envisioned as a stronghold against Mongol invasions. It served both as a fortress and a city, showcasing the ruler‚Äôs ambition and military foresight.

The fort is spread across a massive area, once boasting thick stone walls, massive bastions, and a complex layout that made it nearly impenetrable. Even today, despite being in ruins, the sheer scale and strength of the structure left me in awe.

One fascinating aspect of Tughlakabad‚Äôs history is the curse associated with Saint Nizamuddin Auliya, who allegedly cursed the fort saying "Ya rahe ujjar, ya basey gujjar" ("It will remain deserted or be inhabited by shepherds"). Walking through the ruins, I could feel the eerie, mysterious aura that still lingers.

I was particularly impressed by the monumental gateways, stone corridors, and the remnants of the royal palace and secret passages. Every corner seemed to whisper tales of battles, betrayals, and royal grandeur.

Another highlight of my visit was seeing the Ghiyas-ud-din Tughlaq‚Äôs Tomb, connected to the main fort via a causeway. The tomb, surrounded by gardens, is a beautiful example of Indo-Islamic architecture.

The fort's elevated position gave me panoramic views of the surrounding landscape, and I could easily imagine how this strategic location offered advantages for defense centuries ago.

The experience was a mix of admiration for the architectural brilliance and reflection on how time slowly reclaims even the mightiest of human creations.

I would recommend wearing comfortable shoes, carrying water, and being ready to explore for a few hours, as the fort complex is vast and rugged.

Overall, visiting Tughlakabad Fort was like taking a step back into the 14th century. It deepened my appreciation for Delhi‚Äôs layered history and the incredible stories hidden within its ancient walls.

What's astonishing is that this stunning spot is nestled in the midst of bustling Delhi. It's an unreal experience, transporting you to a peaceful world, far removed from the city's noise and pollution.

I highly recommend visiting Hauz Khas Lake to rejuvenate your senses. Perfect for:

Well done, Delhi Tourism!

Hauz Khas Lake is a serene oasis in the heart of Delhi. The picturesque lake, surrounded by lush greenery and historic monuments, offers a peaceful escape from the city's chaos. Take a stroll along the walking trails, enjoy the scenic views, or simply sit back and relax ‚Äì Hauz Khas Lake is a must-visit destination for nature lovers and those seeking tranquility

During the monsoon season, the Hauz Khas Lake area in South Delhi transforms into a lush green paradise, offering a perfect escape from the city‚Äôs hustle. The rains drench the pathways and revive the dense canopy of trees, giving the entire area a refreshing charm. Walking along the serene lake, one can witness calm waters dotted with ducks and ripples created by gentle showers, all surrounded by thick greenery that looks almost magical under the cloudy skies. The freshness in the air, mixed with the earthy scent of wet soil, makes every step feel rejuvenating.

The pathways, lined with ancient trees and overhanging branches, create a natural tunnel where morning walkers and nature lovers stroll peacefully. On one side, the tranquil waters of the Hauz Khas Lake stretch wide, while on the other side, green lawns and thick forests provide a serene backdrop. The reflections of trees in rainwater puddles add to the enchanting monsoon mood. The tall, old trees standing proudly in clusters showcase the timeless beauty of this heritage landscape.

Visiting this place during the rains is an experience in itself ‚Äì the atmosphere feels calm yet alive, the sound of raindrops mingles with chirping birds, and the vibrant greenery offers a soothing retreat. Whether for a morning walk, photography, or simply to sit and enjoy the view, Hauz Khas Lake in monsoon reminds you how nature can still thrive in the heart of Delhi, offering peace and beauty to anyone who pauses to admire it.

About Hauz Khas Village Ruins

The ruins in Hauz Khas are one of the most amazing sites in Delhi. Tucked away behind the numerous shops in Hauz Khas village, this magnificent monument reveals itself slowly to us as we approach it. The ruins around of are that of the madrasa founded by Sultan Firuz Shah Tughluq in the 14thcentury. It is built on the edge of the tank, which supplied water to the capital city of Siri. It was built by Alauddin Khalji, the ruler of Siri, who called it Hauz i Alai. Later, Firuz Shah repaired it and called it the Hauz Khas. The madrasa is a double storeyed structure, the colonnaded halls probably being lecture halls. At the junction of the two wings of the madrasa is Firuz Shah‚Äôs tomb. It has been recently repaired; however, one of the graves in the chamber was badly damaged yet again. The plaster decoration is however, much more visible after the restoration work. The tomb entrance is enclosed in a most unusual railing pattern. One is not sure what inspired Firuz Shah to come up with this; it is similar to patterns on Buddhist monuments such as the Sanchi stupa. Moving a little ahead there are steps leading down to the lower storey. Here we see some cell like structures: extremely tiny, a small ventilator and an opening acting as a doorway. There probably were rooms for students. There are also some pavilions in the lawns which contain graves. These are probably burials of officers or teachers associated with the madrasa. Our heritage walk also covered monuments in Deer Park. The most prominent monument in the Deer Park is the Bagh i Alam ka Gumbad, a lodi period tomb with an adjacent mosque. Closeby is a small hut like structure called the Kali Gumti. The last stop on our heritage trail in Hauz Khas was the Tuhfewala Gumbad, a Tughluq period tomb with some striking cenotaphs.

It‚Äôs like the mixture of Sankey Tank & Cubbon Park of Banglore.
The whole of Hauz Khas village is aesthetically beautiful. This lake makes it even more a better place. You can take a walk around the lake or find a spot have your small picnic .
Hauz Khas fort is also accessible from here and even the deer park . If you step outside you will have many cute and cozy cafe options too.

Overall, it provides a safe, comfortable, and pleasant journey experience, making travel through Delhi both enjoyable and stress-free.

Very beautiful and well maintained airport as it is India's biggest airport not only in India but also in south east asia. By reaching one terminal to another you have to take shuttle buses as they are too big. Best in class features and modern facilities and when I visited in July there are some musicians playing music and setting the mood on another level. There are many luxury stores and shops are also there. If you are boarding a plane or you have a stop in this airport please try to go advance and get your boarding and security done as it is very big don't wait for last minute. It is the best airport i visited.

Indira Gandhi International Airport in Delhi stands out as one of India‚Äôs finest aviation hubs. Its modern terminals offer excellent cleanliness, efficient immigration, and a wide range of shopping and dining options. The airport‚Äôs layout is intuitive, and business-class travelers benefit from dedicated lanes and lounges. Baggage handling is swift, and staff are generally helpful. However, occasional long queues at check-in and security can be frustrating during peak hours. Some areas could improve maintenance and signage clarity. Overall, the airport delivers a smooth and comfortable experience for most travelers, making it a reliable gateway to India‚Äôs capital city

Delhi Airport is one of the best airports in India. Very clean, well-organized, and easy to navigate. Staff are polite and professional. Facilities like lounges, shopping, and food courts are excellent. Overall, a smooth and comfortable travel experience.

Over the past few years, India‚Äôs airports have truly made a statement ‚Äî and this one is no exception. I travel frequently through this airport and really appreciate how simple and convenient the experience is from the moment you arrive.

If you land early in the morning, there are plenty of coffee outlets and shopping options available. It‚Äôs a great place to grab a quick coffee before heading out. Also they have play area for kids.

Getting a taxi is also hassle-free. Even if you haven‚Äôt pre-booked one, there‚Äôs a taxi counter where you can easily arrange transportation on the spot.

Overall, the arrival experience is smooth and efficient. The airport also offers wheelchair ‚ôø accessible parking üÖøÔ∏è and entrance, adding to the convenience.

Terminal 1 has undergone a complete transformation and now offers a full range of modern amenities. The commercial area has significantly expanded, featuring a wide variety of popular brands. The food court is well-curated, offering an impressive mix of both local and international dining options. Despite the airport's overall expansion and the addition of more entry and exit points, the walking distances remain relatively shorter compared to Terminal 3, making for a more convenient and efficient passenger experience.

Airport is truly impressive. It is very large, super clean, and incredibly well-organized. I loved the smooth flow through check-in and security, and the staff were helpful and polite. One of my favorite things was watching the takeoffs and landings seeing so many planes up close and the overall view from the terminals was wonderful. It‚Äôs a modern, welcoming airport that makes traveling feel easy and enjoyable.

The fairy lights and glass ceiling add a charm to the place that can be captured by a great phone camera. Also, who doesn‚Äôt want to click photos while gorging on some delectable croissants?

placeMetadata.description: Cafe with European short eats & drinks, adjacent to a fashion accessories & clothing store.

Whether you're exploring their diverse Pan European menu or seeking recommendations from their knowledgeable staff, Cafe Dori promises to satisfy your cravings.

reviews.reviewText:
Walked in expecting a decent meal, but ended up loving the whole vibe. The place has this super cozy warm feel, minimal but aesthetic interiors, and a calm buzz that makes you want to just sit and stay a little longer. I had their pesto pasta and it was so good - fresh, flavorful, and comforting.

Great spot to catch up or just work on your laptop.

Cafe Dori in New Delhi offers a unique dining experience with its stylish ambiance, great food, and excellent service. Located in the trendy neighborhood of Mehrauli, this cafe has quickly gained popularity among food enthusiasts looking for something a bit more refined.

The first thing you'll notice when you walk in is the contemporary yet cozy atmosphere. The space is beautifully designed with a mix of modern and rustic touches, perfect for both casual meals and intimate gatherings. The seating is comfortable, and the open kitchen concept adds a sense of openness to the space.

When it comes to the food, Cafe Dori definitely delivers. The menu offers a variety of options, from European-inspired dishes to lighter, health-conscious choices. Highlights include their expertly crafted salads, freshly baked pastries, and delicious mains like the truffle risotto and wood-fired pizzas. The ingredients are of high quality, and the flavors are well-balanced, making each dish a treat for the palate.

However, the one downside is the pricing. The food is undeniably good, but it does come at a premium. While the quality justifies the cost to some extent, the overall experience can feel a bit on the pricier side, especially if you're visiting frequently or ordering multiple courses. The drinks, in particular, can be quite expensive.

Despite the steep prices, the food, service, and overall vibe make Cafe Dori a place worth visiting for those looking to indulge. It‚Äôs a great choice for a special occasion or when you're in the mood to splurge a little. Highly recommended!

The cool ambiance and excellent service made the shop a pleasant experience. I also enjoyed the superb presentation of the food. However, the flavors were a bit bland, and both the pasta and shrimp were slightly overcooked.

As for the katsu chicken sandwich, it could have been better. The chicken was cooked well, but it didn‚Äôt pair nicely with the buttered toasted bread, which made the sandwich feel too heavy and dry. A few more vegetables or a touch of pickle would have helped balance the taste. The fries were also a letdown. They were too oily and could have been larger and less crispy.

Cafe dori has a contemporary yet cozy atmosphere. The space is beautifully designed with a mix of modern and rustic touches, The seating is comfortable,
In terms of food, Cafe Dori definitely delivers. The menu offers a variety of options, from European-inspired dishes to lighter, health-conscious choices. Highlights include their expertly crafted salads n  delicious mains like the truffle risotto. The ingredients are high quality, and the flavors are well-balanced.

A good place to eat‚Ä¶ planned a Sunday breakfast with family‚Ä¶. But got disappointed as most of the menu gets active after 12:30pm.
Spinach scrambled egg 2/5

Will visit again to explore more delicacies‚Ä¶. Recommend place üëçüèª

This place was really good! I love the ambiance and the minimalist look it has. We went there for lunch. Started with some fresh lime sodas. We then ordered a flat bread with chicken and tomatoes etc which was very nice. We also ordered their summer salad that had quinoa, and some fruit. The description had mangoes in it but there weren't any but still it was quite tasty. We then ordered the chicken chermoula over quinoa and spiced yogurt. All very good. We ended it with a delicious cup of cortado. All in all, it was a good lunch.

Cafe Dori is a hidden gem that effortlessly blends elegance with comfort. From the moment you walk in, the warm ambiance and minimalist European d√©cor set the tone for a perfect caf√© experience.

Special mention goes to their Mango Smoothie Bowl ‚Äì a refreshing, vibrant delight packed with natural sweetness and tropical goodness. It's beautifully presented and balanced in flavor, making it not just a dish, but an experience.

The staff is courteous, the service prompt, and every item on the menu reflects attention to quality and detail. Whether you're here for a quiet brunch or a coffee catch-up, Cafe Dori never disappoints. Highly recommended!

Poor place, extremely costly for no reason, bad location. The smoothie was bad and a fly came and sat on the straw. I found this cafe unhygienic. I paid 900+ for two smoothies and a water bottle. And they tasted so bad i did not even drink.

placeMetadata.name: National Zoological Park, Delhi

sources.snippet: The National Zoological Park or commonly known as Delhi Zoo is an extensive zoo that spreads across 176 acres near the Old Fort in Delhi, India. In the middle of a vibrant city lies a 16th century citadel, a green island and a great collection of rare flora and fauna. Around 1350 animals are protected inside the zoo, of different species and families.
sources.shortName: 55 Places to Visit in Delhi 2025, Tourist Places & Attractions

placeMetadata.description: This zoo houses some 130 species, including white tigers, elephants & rhinos (closed on Fridays).
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The National Zoological Park, located near Purana Qila in Delhi, is a renowned zoo in India that was inaugurated in 1959. Home to around 130 species including white tigers, elephants, and rhinos, it covers an expansive area of 176 acres and serves as a breeding ground for endangered animals. The park aims to be a model zoo for the country. Visitors can enjoy the diverse wildlife and lush surroundings while exploring the grounds.
